story_txt: Completed

story:
Our crowdfund campaign has finished, for those who still want to support - we are still receiving Paypal donations. 

Donate here: paypal.me/goldandashes

 

Gold & Ashes

We hope to highlight the humanity and courage of this beautiful community by creating a photo book sharing survivor stories and intimate memories of loved ones.

The photographs and stories documented over the next year will be a part of an exhibition hosted in time for the third year anniversary. We are inviting you to be part of this journey.

All profits made from the Gold & Ashes photo book will go towards supporting mental and emotional wellbeing services for the Grenfell community.

 

This project is supported by Grenfell United, The Kensington & Chelsea Foundation, Candour Creatives and Westway Trust.

What we are fundraising for

To bring this vision to life we are looking to crowdfund £20,000. This will be used to:

1) Print the photo book (including production, post production costs and language translations)

2) Host a week long exhibition (including venue hire, programming, printing exhibition prints etc.) in time for the third year anniversary of the Grenfell tragedy.

3) Design the Gold and Ashes website hosting all the stories we capture (including video content).

 

Feruza's story

Photography by Tara Leigh

My name is Feruza Afewerki and I am a photographer and creative director. I was born in Eritrea and moved to London in 1996 with my family when I was 3. My connection to Grenfell is one of deep love and loss.

Amal Ahmedin was my big sister and one of the most vibrant, stylish and loving people I knew growing up. She lived life to the full. Her infectious joy lit up any room and she lived to see those around her thriving and happy. Her door and heart were always open. Throughout her life she learned to speak six languages because she was always making new friends.

 

 

5 years ago, my family was blessed with a new addition, her daughter Amaya Tuccu. My niece was a creative spirit and 3 years old when her life was cut short. She lived with her parents on the 19th floor of Grenfell Tower. When they moved into their apartment, they began creating a home of joyful memories and this is where they lost their lives on June 14th 2017.

Their lives have inspired me to honour and document the memories of our loved ones, the innocent lives that ended on that night. We as a community are different because of what we’ve walked through. But, we’re still here - a living memorial of what was lost so that their lives are never forgotten. The depth of loss eludes to the depth of love we have experienced. We hold them in our hearts forever and are witnessing the legacy and imprint they have left on our lives.

 

 

The journey I have begun with the Gold and Ashes project has been part of my personal healing process. It has enabled me to connect with others who have experienced the same loss and wish to see more done for their loved one’s memories. While this injustice has caused much hopelessness and anger in a time of grief, this beautiful, diverse and unified community have picked up the pieces and are rebuilding from the ruins with such dignity and love. From campaigning, volunteering their time and looking out for one another.

Wellbeing

When the unimaginable happens there is no manual on how to navigate a path overshadowed in tragedy. As I walk through my own healing and support from a trauma therapist, I’ve become more passionate about raising awareness for trauma aftercare and making professional, holistic support more accessible to assist in building people up along their journey of healing.

 

 

Risks & Challenges

My team of volunteer collaborators hope to create a space for these incredible voices to be heard and stories to be told but we know that a project as complex and nuanced as this means we could never tell the whole story.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this crowdfund and video with your friends and family!

story:
For the past three years, I have published a Calendar called Wild New York featuring my best photos of New York’s Urban Wildlife. This has morphed into a true, huge labor of love. As a token of appreciation, I have selected some awesome rewards available exclusively to the supporters of my campaign as a special one-time opportunity. The rewards include  limited edition autographed prints, and an opportunity for your own private, 90 minute on location, New York City photo shoot!

Why I need your help

High quality production with superior materials costs a lot. Your contribution will help cover half of the production and marketing costs for the calendar, and make it a reality. The calendars are designed in New York City and printed in the USA. 

This past year, I traveled throughout the New York Metro Area searching out and photographing Urban Wildlife. Now I have selected the best of the best photos. In addition to publishing the Wild New York Calendar 2020 I will publish a second calendar, Birds of Prey featuring NYC’s spectacular raptors.  Did you know that New York City has more nesting peregrine falcons than any other city in the world? 

Why this matters?

The calendars not only spread joy, they educate the public about our Urban Wildlife.  Calendar sales are dedicated to help the Wild Bird Fund, NYC's only wildlife rehabilitation facility, care for over 7,000 injured, ill and distressed wildlife.  So you are helping the birds as well as showing your appreciation for our precious wildlife. 

What you get

For the rewards I will make available limited edition autographed prints on Fine Art paper using high quality pigment ink. These prints are being offered to my contributors at special discounted once only price. These prints will help me get this year’s calendars produced and marketed.

How to connect with me?

DennisNewsham.com

On Facebook 

On Instagram

On Twitter

You can email me at: dnewsham@touristpicsnyc.com

story:
Short Summary

About me:

I first documented art as a freelancer for the work of artist friends, using a 35mm camera that I had bought in Japan while serving in the US Air Force during the Korean War. I became very skilled at getting the color accurate in the photographs of paintings (unusually difficult with the technology at that time), and was hired by the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in NYC, to photograph artwork for inclusion in their publications. This work led to a lifetime career of providing documentation for institutions, publishers, collectors and artists. 

My work eventually caught the attention of Georgia O’Keeffe who hired me to photograph a large painting located at her home in New Mexico, which she had completed 3 years earlier. She flew me to Ghost Ranch where I photographed the painting Sky Above Clouds IV, 1965 (using large format 8 X 10 cameras), and this photo was used as the cover of the 1970 Whitney Museum O’Keeffe Retrospective exhibition catalogue. That was the beginning of an almost 20 year connection with O’Keeffe as her preferred photographer for her paintings. I documented all of the works for the first book of reproductions of her paintings, in which she wrote the autobiographical text, published by Viking Press in 1976.  My connection with O’Keeffe for a period of almost two decades afforded me a chance to get to know O’Keeffe as a person, close-up, and this has undoubtedly informed both consciously and subconsciously how I photographed her when the opportunity arose.

My portraits of O’Keeffe are in the collections of the Brooklyn Museum, the Museum of New Mexico, in Santa Fe, and in many private collections. I hope that whoever sees this book will enjoy looking at the photographs, and that they will expand and deepen their perception of her as a person.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This fundraiser will support the production of a book of portraits taken of Georgia O’Keeffe at age 90 that I made in the summer of 1977 when I was a guest of O’Keeffe at her Abiquiu house photographing paintings she was assembling for an upcoming exhibition. During that period Art News commissioned me to take photographs of O’Keeffe for a birthday edition of the magazine and a small selection of the resulting photos were published in the December, 1977 issue of Art News, including my portrait of O’Keeffe on the cover.

That shoot took place over many days and the photos in this book will contain images that show the iconic O’Keeffe as she is known as a strong, unconventional, and intense person. But more surprising, images in the book also show the usually unseen side of her as a compassionate, humorous and relatable person. The book includes photographs of her homes in Abiquiu and Ghost Ranch, New Mexico, and the desert landscapes and bleached animal bones that were the subject of many of her paintings. It also will include photos of the people with whom she was surrounded daily in her homes, as well as photos of O’Keeffe and Juan Hamilton, 60 years her junior, with whom she developed a close and loving friendship during the latter part of her life.

Most of the 65 photographs in this book have never before been published and they will be reproduced in full color at a size of 9”x12”. Included are introductory commentaries by Cody Hartley, Director of the Georgia O’Keeffe Museum, and Barbara Buhler Lynes, the preeminent O’Keeffe scholar, O’Keeffe biographer and author of the Georgia O’Keeffe Catalogue Raisonne. In addition there will be a short introductory essay by me relating to the photographs.

The University of New Mexico Press has been contracted to publish the book in November 2020. As is customary with non-profits, the expense of publishing a large full color art book most often requires that the author provides part of the initial funding for the book. This Indiegogo site has been set up to raise that initial goal of $20,000.00 for this first printing. Below are the perks for donating at various levels and thank you for considering a donation.

 

$25-$49………personal signed thank you card on which I will hand print a photo from the book

$50……………20” X 28” signed vintage poster portrait of O’Keeffe on heavyweight paper

$100………….one signed book 

$200…………two signed books plus a signed poster

$500………....one signed book plus one signed original 11” X 14” exhibition quality photograph                   

$1000………..two signed books plus one signed original 13” X 19” exhibition quality photograph

$3000………. four signed books, two signed original exhibition quality 13” X 19” photographs,  plus mention in the acknowledgment page of the book as a donor to the project

*MIX & MATCH:

Any of the photographs shown in the video can be substituted for any of the ones shown in the perks section. Also the  photographs in the perks section can be substituted for each other. Additionally, the image itself that was used for the poster can be had as a signed exhibition quality photograph and substituted for any in the perks section.

(The photographs will be on either 11” X 14” or 13” X 19” archival paper. The actual size of the image will be as large as possible on that paper with ¼” white borders)

story:
Postcards From A Pandemic

 

     Hi my name is Star Foreman, I am an editorial photographer based out of Los Angeles and best known for my work with the LA Weekly. Like most of you I was horrified by the Covid-19 outbreak and scared by the subsequent stay home order. 

     When the order first came down, and we found out it would be months (not days or weeks,) I felt it was imperative that somebody get a comprehensive portrait of Los Angeles during this time. As I prepped for the project and started creating images I realized that I needed to expand it to all of Southern California. 

     Over the course of 32 shoot days, one day on one day off, I traveled to every single location within Southern CA that I could think of that would be visually affected from a stay home order. From Santa Barbara to San Diego I traveled to beaches, malls, public parks. Really, any area that would usually be filled with people I photographed empty. 

     What will stay with me for the rest of my life are two things,

1. The Silence.

We are so used to the background noise of other people. I realized this when you standing in the middle of Hollywood blvd on a weekday afternoon and i was all alone. No cars, no people, nothing.  It affected me in a way that words can not adequately describe. I felt like we had all been cut off from one another and left on our own private islands (Animal Crossing reference not intended.)

2. The Smells.

The world smelled so good. Blooming heather on the bluffs of Malibu, jasmine in Santa Barbara, Pershing Square scrubbed off all the urine- the world without people smells amazing. 

What Now?

    At this point you might be thinking, "Why do I need to contribute to your Indiegogo campaign, the project is over?"

      I wish that were true. in order to complete my project I invested about $2800 in equipment, gas, and other essentials needed to make to project a reality. I estimate to finish the project will be between $2000-$3500 and that doesn't even include my stretch goals. 

     I have taken 18,500 images over the past two months and 32 shoot days. Each of those images needs to be color corrected, embedded with metadata that includes the date, time and location of each image. After this they must be outputted onto at least two external hard-drives, and uploaded to a cloud account, for safekeeping. They must then be registered with the copyright office. 

     Furthermore

     I plan to build a website (http://portraitofapandemic.com) that will give people the ability to see the entire project . The idea is to have 30-60 separate galleries, with each one having the name of the city and the date it was taken, for me to see and hopefully  in the future remember and teach those who come after us, what it looks like when only the essential and desperate are out and about. 

     I believe what I have created is unique and it will hopefully exist long after I have passed into irrelevance. 

 

Final Projects

 

1. A website that will give viewers a window into Southern CA during the historic Stay Home Order. 

2. A series of essays, or even quotes, from people in Southern Ca to go with the images. Stories and anecdotes of their experiences during the lockdown. To get these I will need to actively recruit people to write these. I estimate this alone will take me 100 or more hours to accomplish. 

Stretch Goals

1. A museum or art exhibition featuring 50-100 of the most affecting images from the series. 

2. A coffee table book.

3. A series of actual postcards that people could keep or mail.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

      "Hey Star, like I love this thing you have made but I am a Ren faire worker who just lost a year's income, I can't really afford to give you money right now."

     If you love the idea of this project reaching its conclusion, but can't help financially, don't worry. I would love if you would take the time out of your day to tell your more well-heeled friends about this project and encourage them to help if they can.

story:
I have been traveling for the past year and eight months.  I spent one year in Africa, working on HIV/AIDS initiatives.  Seven months in Thailand teaching English to novice monks and high school students and now I am in the Philippines working on establishing an annual arts & culture festival.  I plan on staying on the road for the foreseeable future, volunteering and giving back in any way that I can.

The problem:  My passion (taking photographs/video) has come to a halt.  My camera recently fell off a table as I was leaving to go on a photo shoot.  Seeing as how I am only volunteering (not making money), I do not have the necessary funds to purchase a new camera on my own.

If you could please do me a favor and offer anything that you can towards a new camera, I would forever be indebted to you.  I will make a series of photos on any topic that you would like.  When I get picked up by National Geographic, I will make you my honorary assistant! :)

If you cannot assist through a donation, would you mind spreading the word.  My love and passion of capturing the world in varying cultures/countries is at a stand still and it kills me every day that I am unable to focus just right on a young girl's smiling face.

Thank you in advance for your assistance and any efforts that you make on my behalf! I love you all!

story:
Üdv Mindenkinek!


Többen valószínűleg ismeritek a nevemet, a fotóimat, illetve biztosan vagytok páran, akik most látják ezeket a fotókat először, természetesen mindenkit köszöntök ezen az oldalon :)
A tavalyi évben elmaradt, de annyi érdeklődő volt idén, hogy úgy gondoltam belevágok a naptár tervezésbe. Kissé a bőség zavarában is voltam, de ennek ellenére nehéz is volt összerakni azokat a képeket, amelyek végülis több hetes válogatás és dilemma után bekerültek a naptárakba.
Bizony, van többesszám, hiszen 4 féle témát ölel fel a 4 naptár, amelyek - a nyomdai egyszerűség kedvéért - egy méretben lesznek elérhetőek, viszont két képarányban.
Két számomra igen kedves téma, a montázsok és a tájképek esetében a méretarány négyzetes, 30x30 cm, ahogy a képen is látszódik, középen spirálozva, felül lyukasztva. Ez a megoldás azért is jó, mert a falra akasztva nagy méretben láthatjuk a választott fotóinkat, ugyanakkor a naptár része is előttünk van, amin bőségesen áll rendelkezésre hely, hogy felírjuk napi teendőinket, kedves emlékeinket :) 
Itt láthatjátok az első képet és a naptár részt, mindkettő 30x30 cm, tehát a falon 30x60 cm lesz majd!

A másik két téma, egy a vihar és villámfotók szerelmeseinek, a másik Szeged városát imádóknak készült, A3-as méretű, 2/3 (azaz normál) képaránnyal, fekvő képekkel. Az elrendezés itt is hasonlatos, felül a fotó lyukasztással, középen spirálozva, alul nagy méretű naptár rész, valamint extraként még hónaponként egy viharos/villámos és egy szegedi fotó is került rá, ezek négyzetes vágásúak, fölöttük egy kis vonalas jegyzet is helyet kapott!
Itt láthatjátok az első képet és a naptár részt, mindkettő 42x30 cm, tehát a falon 42x60 cm lesz majd!


A fentebb látható látványtervek 90%-ban megegyeznek a végleges verzióval, ez csak annyit jelent, hogy kisebb változások még lehetnek rajta, de lényegében így fog kinézni.
A lapok mindkét oldala nyomtatott,  elő és hátlappal együtt 14 lapból áll majd.
Ami az árakat illeti, a négyzetes képek 2600 Ft-ba kerülnek, az Indiegogo-n azonban USD vagy EUR alapú rendszer működik (utóbbi esetében csak PayPal utalás lehetséges, míg az USD-nél bankkártyás utalás is lehetséges, ezért lett ez), ezért az ehhez legközelebb eső érték a 9 USD, míg a normál A3 méretarányú képeknél az ár 3200 Ft, ehhez a legközelebbi a 11 USD (november 8-ai középárfolyam szerint)
A faliképek 2 féle méretben kaphatóak a méretarány miatt, 50x50 és 60x40 cm-esek, hpvc lemezen, kétoldalú ragasztóval, elég csak felnyomni a falra és fennmarad! Áruk egységesen 4650 Ft.
Természetesen Szegeden és a relatíve szűk környezetében élőknek a személyes átvételt javaslom, minden egyéb esetben pedig postai úton juthatsz hozzá a naptáradhoz és faliképedhez :)

FONTOS! 

AKI NEM TUDJA SZEMÉLYESEN ÁTVENNI A NAPTÁRÁT, AZOKTÓL SZERETNÉM KÉRNI, HOGY AZ ADOTT "PERK"-EKHEZ MÉG ADJON HOZZÁ 3-4 DOLLÁRT, AMI FEDEZI A CSOMAGOLÁSI ÉS BELFÖLDI POSTAKÖLTSÉGET.  ÍGY A 9 DOLLÁROS TÉTELNÉL 12 USD, A 11 DOLLÁROS ESETÉBEN PEDIG 14 DOLLÁR.

AMI A FALIKÉPEKET ILLETI, KÖRÜLBELÜL 2 EZER FORINT A BELFÖLDI POSTA, ÍGY ENNEK AZ ÁRA 7 DOLLÁRRAL NŐ, AZAZ 23 DOLLÁRT KÉREK UTALNI, NEM SZEMÉLYES ÁTVÉTEL ESETÉN.
Külföldi posta esetén egyeztessünk, mert az kb mindenhová más!
KÖSZÖNÖM!

Többen valószínűleg ismeritek a nevemet, a fotóimat, illetve biztosan vagytok páran, akik most látják ezeket a fotókat először, természetesen mindenkit köszöntök ezen az oldalon :)A tavalyi évben elmaradt, de annyi érdeklődő volt idén, hogy úgy gondoltam belevágok a naptár tervezésbe. Kissé a bőség zavarában is voltam, de ennek ellenére nehéz is volt összerakni azokat a képeket, amelyek végülis több hetes válogatás és dilemma után bekerültek a naptárakba.Bizony, van többesszám, hiszen 4 féle témát ölel fel a 4 naptár, amelyek - a nyomdai egyszerűség kedvéért - egy méretben lesznek elérhetőek, viszont két képarányban.Két számomra igen kedves téma, a montázsok és a tájképek esetében a méretarány négyzetes, 30x30 cm, ahogy a képen is látszódik, középen spirálozva, felül lyukasztva. story:
I am Taehyun who is a commercial photographer based in Seoul, South Korea. Mainly shooting cosmetic, Jewerly, fashion items etc...( http://studioxeno.alltheway.kr )  Most of the time I usually spend time with my clients in the studio, but when I have a free time or vacation I am focused on my landscape project.

Since 2014, I've photographed landscape for personal project such as Turkey, Hong Kong, Japan, USA and South Korea.

This project is sharing amazing image of mother nature around the world. The reason why I do this project is to share all of the wondering worlds to many people.

In this year, I am going to photograph in Hawaii from Oct. 1st to Oct. 15th 2017 and someday in Feb 2018. I will be focused on amazing scenery in Hawaii 2017 through 2018.

After Hawaii project is done (Middle of March 2018), I will e mail contributors(above $200 perk contributors) 30 best selected images to pick ONE image for each contributor(more details in Perk). In a few weeks, all contributors send me e mail back to confirm what you like to have. All selected images from Hawaii project will be posted on my studio web site to share many people in the world. (http://studioxeno.alltheway.kr) This project is already began, my flight tickets are ready and my passion is fully charged.

As I mention that I am a professional photographer, my photographes are (16"x20") selling worldwide over $1000 each . In other word, you don't need to worry or doubt about me. All I want is all contributors could enjoy worthy photogrpahs from me.

I wish my first compaign going well and all contributors will be delighted. Therefore, I could do more landscape projects next few years and share the world with many people. Please take the time and share my campaign with friends. Your interest can make a big difference to the success of this project. I hope all landscape images into a series of limited-edition prints for exhibition.

Sincerely,

Award:

2015 One Eyeland Photography Awards Finalist in NATURE “At the moment”  Finalist in NATURE “Lower Antelope Canyon” 

2015 IPA International Photography Awards (U.S.A) Honorable Mention in ONE SHOT “Busan”

2014 IPA International Photography Awards (U.S.A) Honorable Mention in Advertising-Self Promotion “A mass of …” Honorable Mention in Advertising-Special Effects “Untitled”

안녕하세요? 저는 서울에서 화장품,쥬얼리,패션아이템  촬영하고 있는 광고사진가 김태현 입니다. 저는 이번에 스튜디오라는 제한적인 공간을 벗어나 전세계 많은 이들과 함께 나눌수 있는 풍경사진 프로젝트로 크라우드펀딩을 진행해 보려합니다. 크라운드 펀딩은 여러분께서 저의 프로젝트에 금전적으로 도움을 주시면 프로젝트가 잘 마무리 된 후, 촬영한 사진을 도움주신 금액에 맞게 사진으로 돌려드리는 것입니다. 크라우드 펀딩 금액은 $5(감사인사), $20(PC나 핸드폰에 배경을 사용 할 수 있는 JPG파일), $100(5"x7"사진), $200(8"x10" 사진2장), $300(8"x10" 스탠트액자), $500(11"x14" 디아섹액자), $1000(16"x20" 디아섹액자) 로 되어 있습니다. 그리고 BACK IT 버튼을 누르시면 후원 하시고  금액 만큼 펀딩 할 수 있습니다.

2014년 부터 터키,홍콩,일본,미국 그리고 대한민국의 잘 알려지지 않은 아름다운 풍경사진을  촬영 하고 있습니다. 사실 이 풍경사진 프로젝트의 시작은 여러가지 이유로 전세계 아름다운 풍경을 볼 기회가 없는 분들과 함께 나누고자는 뜻 으로 시작했습니다. 사진가로써 아름다운 풍경을 촬영하거나 접할 기회가 많이 있습니다. 그럴때마다 이 아름다운 광경을 많은 분들과 함께 나눈다면 더할나이 없이 좋지 않을까란 생각에 풍경사진 프로젝트를 시작하게 되었습니다.

이번 2017년 프로젝트는 미국 하와이의 아름다움을 담는 프로젝트 입니다. 올 10월과 내년 2월 두차례에 걸쳐 하와이의 여러곳을 담아 많은 분들과 함께 나누고자 합니다.

하와이 프로젝트의 촬영이 마무리 되는 2018년 3월경, 베스트 사진 30장을 추려서 ($200이상 지원해 주신분께) 각자의 이메일로 저해상 사진을 보내드립니다. 이메일을 받고 몇주 안에 각자가 마음에 드는 사진을 골라 주시면 그 사진을 프린트 또는 액자프린트를 마무리 한 후 배송해 드립니다.

이 프로젝트에 참여 하신다면 여러분들과 함께 만 프로젝트가 완성 될 것입니다. 물론 아름다운 하와이 사진을 직접 소장 할 수 있는 기회이 기도 합니다.

이번 하와이 프로젝트가 잘 진행이 된다면, 앞으로 다가올 다른 프로젝트 또한 성공적으로 진행이 될 것으로 기대 됩니다. 꼭 참여 하셔서 사진도 소장하시고 전세계 많은 분들과 함께 아름다운 풍경사진을 나누시길 바랍니다. 감사합니다.

 

 

Stand 8"x10" frame sample

이번 2017년 프로젝트는 미국 하와이의 아름다움을 담는 프로젝트 입니다. 올 10월과 내년 2월 두차례에 걸쳐 하와이의 여러곳을 담아 많은 분들과 함께 나누고자 합니다.
하와이 프로젝트의 촬영이 마무리 되는 2018년 3월경, 베스트 사진 30장을 추려서 ($200이상 지원해 주신분께) 각자의 이메일로 저해상 사진을 보내드립니다. 이메일을 받고 몇주 안에 각자가 마음에 드는 사진을 골라 주시면 그 사진을 프린트 또는 액자프린트를 마무리 한 후 배송해 드립니다.
이 프로젝트에 참여 하신다면 여러분들과 함께 만 프로젝트가 완성 될 것입니다. 물론 아름다운 하와이 사진을 직접 소장 할 수 있는 기회이 기도 합니다.
이번 하와이 프로젝트가 잘 진행이 된다면, 앞으로 다가올 다른 프로젝트 또한 성공적으로 진행이 될 것으로 기대 됩니다. 꼭 참여 하셔서 사진도 소장하시고 전세계 많은 분들과 함께 아름다운 풍경사진을 나누시길 바랍니다. 감사합니다.
 

 

Stand 8"x10" frame sample

story:
It is a publication based on a journey of over two years by someone in search of a "fugitive self". An exploration of my identity as a foreigner and as an artist who seems to have entered "their" zone from "another planet". It is journey symbolic to our collective search for our sense of belonging. 

My journey of over two years encompassed meetings with over 120 people who work in the arts, and the images all feature myself and "the other". "Self-portraits" have always been an expression and exploration of identity and our identity evolves partly dependent on how we relate with the rest of the world. In this project, I use "Dual-Self-Portraits" to examine my identity and rapport with "the other". Of course, it would be impossible to exclude my background from the story. I was born in Hong Kong, lived for 20 years outside of Hong Kong (US and UK mainly then 2 years in Singapore) while my family lives somewhere else. Yet I have always felt a strong sense of belonging in Italy: its beauty, language, art and my friends...... So, if I were to spend most of my time in Italy, "how would I fit in?" I undertook a dream-like journey with great curiosity and wonder, looking through art and meeting artists everywhere in Italy. Upon seeing their artwork, I feel a personal empathy and wanted to meet the creators. In the photo-session, I enter the frame which I had pre-set, likened to the process of me as a foreigner adapting into "the other's" environment. My new connections gave me additional sense of belonging as a foreigner and an artist in Italy, and in turn, with myself, tapping into the unconscious.

As Carl Jung had called it, we make our decisions with a strong influence by the unconscious (a storehouse of repressed memories specific to the individual and our ancestral past), a few years of exploration can only uncover what might take a lifetime and beyond to be ever known. Project "9_9" serves as another attempt to discover more of my own mystery. (My first book "Fragments of Grey Matter" which won a prize in Japan explored part of that in another form but it also explored the concept of perception and unconscious). There is a reason for this project to be titled "9_9"--it is a symbolic representation of my roots (the 9th day of the 9th lunar calendar month is my chinese calendar birthday and 99 is one off from the perfect score of 100) and the texts in the book will go through this subject.

The EUR 39000 covers costs only, no profit. SKIRA will be publishing 9_9 in May 2017. The book contains an Interview with me and a critical art essay by Fortunato D'Amico (Curator at Fondazione Pistoletto), an essay by Yen Lin Kong, Master's in Photography, a Prologue by me and an Epilogue by John Clang, one of my favorite teachers. The portraits will be printed in bicromia (black & white duotone) to show the full depths. A color section called "Treasure Box" (symbolising a newly created third space between "me" and "the other") will include thoughts & drawings dedicated to me by the artists and other backstage materials. 

Please support this project in any way you can. Art nourishes everyone and though we don't all want to be/aren't all artists by profession, we can be Artists in life. My way of examining life is symbolic of our collective search. It is in a way, my contribution to the contemporary art world where a new photographic language has been invented alongside with subjects of various importance in history for years to come. 

On the "Perks" page, if you would like to see an option which is not yet available please also let me know through the "Ask a Question" button.

story:
We live in the outer spiral arm of a galaxy known as the Milky Way. Our galaxy is described as a Barred Grand Spiral Galaxy as that is what it looks like from a distance, from inside however, this is not what we see. In the country when looking heavenward on a clear night, at the right time of year, there is a bright mass crossing the sky. This is the centre of the Milky Way.

I started planning this project six months ago, since then I have created a 10x8 panel mosaic of this region, currently have it hanging up on the wall. My original intention was to create the largest amateur image using a Nikon D810a, but shortly after I decided that if I am going to undertake this project, I should go all in!

If you would like to have a look at this picture in higher resolution click the link below. What I have uploaded is a less heavily processed version as it preserves detail better than the print version.

https://easyzoom.com/image/95587

To put into perspective the size of this region, I've made a picture that shows where it sits in relation to the interior of the Milky Way as a whole.

When originally deciding upon this project I did struggle with the size of the mosaic. All three are approximately the same size overall but show different regions. I ultimately opted for the 25x10 panel as I felt it gave the best balance.

The Past:

The current mosaic that I have done was photographed with a 677mm F/5.21 lens and a Nikon D700 (reasonably old now but still does a pretty good job). The Nikon D700 has a full frame sensor (36x24mm) and is considered to be the equivalent to 35mm film in size.

For the 65 billion pixel photograph, the Nikon D700 is not up to the task. It is a colour camera with an anti-aliasing filter, quite noisy, has very little hydrogen alpha response (the red/magenta nebula)  and requires to be manually operated/controlled.

As harsh as I am being on what I used to capture the 1 gigapixel mosaic above, I will give it some perspective. The entire picture took 80 minutes, less than an hour and a half. It is an 80 panel mosaic so each panel is a single 60s image taken with what I have described as an older, noisy & not overly sensitive camera.

Comparisons & Examples:

It would be reasonable to ask the question, "Why go through all of this extra trouble?" when the Nikon D700 and current telescope have done quite a good job already. This is best and easiest way to show its importance is with real world examples.

On the left we have an image of the Lagoon nebula which was taken as a part of my 1 gigapixel image of the Milky Way. On the right is a false colour image (same as what Hubble does with images such as the Pillars of Creation) I took with a different camera about 10 months ago. In this comparison we are not as interested in the depth and contrast in the detail, only the star sizes. At this level there isn't a huge perceivable difference but the following two companions show close ups of the same regions, take note of the star size differences.

Earlier on I mentioned that there is an approximate 8x increase in resolution, I hope this helps illustrate my point. This comparison is also to you an idea of the level of detail that is going to be achieved in the final 65 billion pixel image.

How Big is Big??

The above video shows relative image sizes. I starts from a 100 pixel block moving out through the resolution of HD TV, the Nikon D700 and all the way out to the 65 billion pixel mosaic.
 

This short video shows a zoom in towards the Lagoon Nebula on a half resolution version of the Milky Way; ~240 million pixels.

The Future:

Instead I will be using a monochrome camera that has a pixel density of a 65+mp full frame camera, a step up from the 12mp D700. As this sensor has approx. 1/4 of the area of the D700 it changes from a 25x10 to a 50x20 panel (1000 panels) and will total approx 65 billion pixels as a final image. I have been using a ZWO ASI1600MM-C for a few months but will shortly be transitioning to a QHY163M, same sensor but better architecture. Although the sensor is quite a bit smaller than the D700 it is 5x more sensitive, has a quarter of the read noise (electronic readout noise) and will be able to achieve 8x the resolution.

To be able to take it deeper and with better colour fidelity, the final image will be captured through 5 filters making it a HaLRGB; a hydrogen emission boosted colour image. To help with this a larger telescope will be used, equivalent to a 600mm F/3 lens. Due to being a larger aperture than my current telescope, it captures approx. 2.3x the amount of light and has a shorter focal length which gives this telescope an overall 3x increase in signal. What this means is that on paper, what my current telescope can capture in six hours the new one will capture in two.

The last piece in this puzzle is a work station. My laptop (15" MacBook Pro) has been able to deal with everything I've thrown at it so far but when it comes to processing an image file that will be a fraction shy of 1 terabyte in size, it will struggle; yes the final image will fill a standard 1TB external HD. Depending on the number of layers used in Photoshop for editing, it could push 1.5TB in size. There will also be approx. 8TB of associated files needed to create the final image but they can be spread out over multiple smaller HDs. Dealing with 1000 individual panels is quite easy albeit very time consuming. Combining and editing a thousand 65 MP images requires an extra boost in power.

Where to from here:

This is a project that I will not be starting until May. The telescope for this project is not likely to arrive until late April, the team in at Officina Stellare tell me that they're just waiting on the installation of the optical components right now (March). By May the panels are suitably high enough above the horizon at a reasonable hour; at the moment I have a window between 3-4:30 am where they are high enough above the horizon and the sun isn't starting to come up.

As is mentioned above, this is going to be a 1000 panel mosaic but this is just a minimum, it really doesn't have to stop there. The current largest astronomical image is 46 billion pixels and a zoomable version of that can be found below. It not only spans the width of what I have planned (albeit not as high) but all the way to the Eta Carina Nebula near the constellation Crux (Southern Cross).

http://gds.astro.rub.de

Going further adds a considerable amount of time, not only in capturing the images but in processing and power required to get it finished. Arguably I could do the entire view of the southern hemisphere given years of patience and hard work.

The Next Step:

The next step is having a successful campaign! The reason this has been set up as a Flexible Funding Campaign is that I plan to complete this irrespective of how this campaign goes. If for whatever reason it isn't fully funded everyone will still get what they have pledged, some may just take a bit longer to fulfil (processing will take considerably longer). It is a project that I do want to complete so I am putting considerable amounts of money in as it is. A successful campaign allows for more to be done faster and at a higher quality. A more than successful campaign potentially allows a much larger image than 65 billion pixels!

This is where all of you come in, the masses that like the heading "The Worlds Biggest...". This is more than just a big picture though, it is a glimpse into our past, our beginnings. Carl Sagan is rebound of saying that we are "Star Dust", we are the ash born from the embers of the universes past. 

Whether you simply want a zoomable image of the Milky Way to look over and see what you yourself can discover (find all of the open star clusters that will be in this field) or you want a picture t hang up on your wall because, lets face it, space pictures are awesome; you can be a part of a bigger project, one to create the Worlds Largest Astronomical Image.

 

Perks:

Zoomable Image: Although a full resolution version of the Worlds Largest Astronomical Image will be put online, it will only be visible to anyone who pledges for this project for a time. This perk will allow all backers not only access to the full image BUT access to it while I am putting it together AND any extended size that this image goes to. It will be made fully public 12-24 months after the project is complete. 

Assortment of Backgrounds: There are a considerable amount of stellar objects and beautiful regions that fall into the field that this project covers. Some of them are clearly visible in the EasyZoom link towards the top of the page, regions such as the Lagoon, Triffid & Catspaw nebulas. Although not in that field, the Eagle Nebula (most notable for the Pillars of Creation) will make an appearance. Backgrounds for phones, laptops and desktops will be made from the various regions covered in this project.

Photobook (Digital/Print): Much like the background images, a photobook will be designed and created out of the many wonderful regions that have been captured. The book will be 15" x 11", printed on high quality 190 GSM paper.

Small Framed Print: You can get a print that has a maximum dimensions of 12" x 8" (the matting and frame increase the size more than this). This means that the current 1 gigapixel image is a 12" x 6" print being a 2:1 aspect ratio.

Medium Framed Print: You can get a print that has a maximum dimensions of 18" x 12" (the matting and frame increase the size more than this). The 65 billion pixel mosaic has an aspect ratio of 3.3:1 making it a true panorama and also an 18" x 5.45" print (this is just a back of the envelope calculation, accurate dimensions will not be possible until the project is complete).

Large Framed Print: You can get a print that has a maximum dimensions of 24" x 16" (the matting and frame increase the size more than this). Any other region can be chosen to be printed, the best way of doing this will eventually be through the zoomable image where you can screen shot the region you would like.

story:
Justice is the essence of our survival, and without it no one prospers, because we would be subject to poverty, hatred and war. - David E. Kelly

13 years ago on September 11, 2002, as a Freelance Photographer  David E. Kelly released a copyrighted photo-poster of the Opening Game Ceremony of The 2001 World Series in Phoenix Arizona titled "Remembering September 11, 2001" to help raise money to contribute to the Widows and Orphans of 9/11 support fund. It was the first ever tribute to the tragedy of September 11, 2001 at a major sporting event. Unfortunately, a former major league baseball player who is now a criminal felon counterfeited the poster and distributed and sold it all around the world to raise money for himself and his criminal associates, family and friends. Yes, the copyright thief earned millions from an altered image of the photo poster and sold the counterfeit print in over 108 vendors worldwide. The first court case has dragged out since 2006, but more legal work is necessary to gain true justice in order to restore my photography business to it's prior status.

Unfortunately, the counterfeiter was allowed to go Scott Free from the criminal prosecution of his crimes, and is still roaming the countryside scamming people. The story can be found online at www.thestolenimage.com. It truly is a harrowing story, and no one should be made to suffer when you ask the authorities including Sheriff Joe Arpaio to help stop a criminal, and then he gets in bed with the criminal to earn profits off the worldwide distribution of the counterfeit print as well. Please view the link here to see the criminal and his partner in crime. https://www.facebook.com/347208991969846/photos...

Nevertheless, as the true copyright owner, I was driven to poverty and homelessness, and experienced depression, because I exhausted all of my means mainly towards protecting my United States Copyright when no one else seemed to care, not even those who claimed to represent me in two different courts. I fought through some of the toughest battles of my life as a Pro Se litigant, when my attorney's failed to represent me in the best interest of the law.

Today, I am asking the public for help in restoring my life and business, and to help with my legal expenses in the second court case that is pending in the United States Federal District Court against Sheriff Joe Arpaio who sold the counterfeit prints too, while knowing that there was a court case against the counterfeit thief in his own Maricopa County Superior Court, and when I had went to him and his deputies on several occasions for help to stop and arrest the counterfeiter. 

http://www.courthousenews.com/2015/12/22/photographer-says-arpaio-gave-felon-a-pass.htm


The last 13 years have been rough for me having to watch these criminals rip my business off and none of the police authorities would help me stop them. This is not the America that I want to know, where justice is perverted and ethics and morals do not matter to us as a society and nation of laws.

In the meantime, I am having to deal with some hardened criminals that will not stop selling my United States copyrighted photo image and must now go into Federal Court in Phoenix, Arizona to put a stop to their illegal activities once and for all.

Your contribution is very well appreciated, and thank you for taking the time to read about my situation. 

2016 Copyright, David E. Kelly; All Rights Reserved.
story_txt:
Justice is the essence of our survival, and without it no one prospers, because we would be subject to poverty, hatred and war. - David E. Kelly
13 years ago on September 11, 2002, as a Freelance Photographer  David E. Kelly released a copyrighted photo-poster of the Opening Game Ceremony of The 2001 World Series in Phoenix Arizona titled "Remembering September 11, 2001" to help raise money to contribute to the Widows and Orphans of 9/11 support fund. It was the first ever tribute to the tragedy of September 11, 2001 at a major sporting event. Unfortunately, a former major league baseball player who is now a criminal felon counterfeited the poster and distributed and sold it all around the world to raise money for himself and his criminal associates, family and friends. Yes, the copyright thief earned millions from an altered image of the photo poster and sold the counterfeit print in over 108 vendors worldwide. The first court case has dragged out since 2006, but more legal work is necessary to gain true justice in order to restore my photography business to it's prior status.
Unfortunately, the counterfeiter was allowed to go Scott Free from the criminal prosecution of his crimes, and is still roaming the countryside scamming people. The story can be found online at www.thestolenimage.com. It truly is a harrowing story, and no one should be made to suffer when you ask the authorities including Sheriff Joe Arpaio to help stop a criminal, and then he gets in bed with the criminal to earn profits off the worldwide distribution of the counterfeit print as well. Please view the link here to see the criminal and his partner in crime. https://www.facebook.com/347208991969846/photos...
Nevertheless, as the true copyright owner, I was driven to poverty and homelessness, and experienced depression, because I exhausted all of my means mainly towards protecting my United States Copyright when no one else seemed to care, not even those who claimed to represent me in two different courts. I fought through some of the toughest battles of my life as a Pro Se litigant, when my attorney's failed to represent me in the best interest of the law.
Today, I am asking the public for help in restoring my life and business, and to help with my legal expenses in the second court case that is pending in the United States Federal District Court against Sheriff Joe Arpaio who sold the counterfeit prints too, while knowing that there was a court case against the counterfeit thief in his own Maricopa County Superior Court, and when I had went to him and his deputies on several occasions for help to stop and arrest the counterfeiter.

In the meantime, I am having to deal with some hardened criminals that will not stop selling my United States copyrighted photo image and must now go into Federal Court in Phoenix, Arizona to put a stop to their illegal activities once and for all.
Your contribution is very well appreciated, and thank you for taking the time to read about my situation.

story:
Human Rights Defenders is a non-violent resistance organisation operating mainly in Hebron, a Palestinian city notorious for violent attacks by ultra-right wing religious settlers, house demolitions and a permanent military lockdown that bans residents from entering the high street of their own city. Local grass roots organisations such as HRD, with the support of international and Israeli human rights NGOs have been fighting back. 

Their weapons are video cameras used to document the attacks by settlers and soldiers, and computers to tell the world about them. Nothing threatens Israel's illegal military occupation more than the truth. But when activists Imad and Awni Abu Shamsiyya tried to travel to Lebanon to tell their story on television, Israeli border authorities confiscated their camera and computer, and prevented them from leaving their own country. 

The aim of this campaign is to provide much needed video camera and computer equipment. This will help to ensure that the residents of the threatened Palestinian communities of Hebron are not silenced in their fight for justice and an end to the illegal occupation of their city. 

For more information: 

http://www.haaretz.com/opinion/.premium-1.644080

http://unispal.un.org/unispal.nsf/47d4e277b48d9d3685256ddc00612265/3f1282254b7d083a85257c320056b46e?OpenDocument

http://www.btselem.org/topic/settler_violence

http://www.thenational.ae/world/middle-east/settlers-keep-hebron-family-prisoners-in-their-own-home#page1

Also, check out Human Rights Defenders' Official YouTube Channel https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCcp4VPvAxptCYutqEqf7SJA

story:
So tell me more about this project... 

This is What Philadelphia Looks Like is a photographic project striving to create common ground.  Diversity is a multifaceted fragment of life. There are countless ways to describe how one individual may be different from another, yet alone how one group differs from the next. And while a multitude of differences may exist – there are just as many, if not more, similarities. This is What Philadelphia Looks Like aims to exploit these similarities, no matter how minute. We are focused on raising awareness of the stereotypic nature humans possess, and hope to create dissonance and disassociation by challenging common misconceptions and labels applied to those viewed as the “other”. While creating this discord, we concurrently hope to swap these adverse stereotypes with sentiments of understanding and relatability. We hope that a young paraplegic girl is admired for her bright smile and silly faces, and not sneered at and called a “crippled”. We hope that the man surrounded by his kids and wife is viewed as a family man and great dad, and not deemed a terrorist simply because he’s Muslim. Conversation is the best mode of learning – and as they say, a picture is worth a thousand words.

This project is in no way a means to erase our diversity. Diversity is beautiful, and it is because of it that this universe has grown to where it is today. The Co-Intelligence Institute gave a great example on this. They said, “You need diverse parts to make a bicycle. A barrel of handlebars won't do the job… Likewise, an ecosystem is made up of diverse species, making up complex food chains and cycles that keep the whole thing going. Relationship, community, interdependence, mutuality -- even the entire economic system with all its different jobs and products and services and forms of exchange -- are all totally dependent on diversity”.  Diversity is a necessity, but when used as a divisive measure, being “different” can result in misunderstandings, alienation, and dominance. This project aims to show the commonality between us all, despite those differences, and hopes that with a bit of understanding, these differences can come to be celebrated rather than shunned.

 

 

Why Philadelphia?

This is my home of course! I'm an event photographer situated in Philadelphia and have always had an adoration for the city's great diversity. But as the project grows it’s only right to include more cities – so be on the lookout!

 

What can you do?

This project relies on the acquisition of a Photo booth. Photo booth’s are awesome because of it’s inclusiveness nature and invitation to be yourself. The $13,000 budget will cover the cost of the photo booth, the printer, one cartridge of ink, paper, and the programs to share the images across social media.

 

Perks, Perks, Perks!

I have a number of perks ranging from postcards to canvas'. Most perks will be personalized with my "This is What Philadelphia Looks Like" logo, but there are a few listed in which you have an option to choose your preferred image. These options will be on my site KapturePhiladelphia.com. Feel free to browse around and see just how awesome of a city Philadelphia is, but if you wish to simply find your image options to choose from, click the link "Stock". (INTERNATIONAL BACKERS: To control shipping costs, I've limited shipping to the United States. If you're outside the US and want to pledge, contact me and I'll give you a shipping estimate).

Cool logo --- tell me more about it

For one, I have an awesome graphic designer! I really wanted to showcase Philly's diversity, so we made sure to include men and women from different races and backgrounds. The collage consists of 9 different images which were then formatted into an outline of the city. We played with a few different fonts and colors, and voila! 

 

How can I follow the project?

You can follow the project on the Instagram page @ThisIsWhatPhillyLooksLike

 

 

Risks and Challenges

The biggest risk is the step not taken. The second biggest is not stepping again. My current challenge will be finding organizers who will understand and see the great potential in this project and agree to hosting the booth during their event.

story:
THE ROAD I CALL HOME

 

Portraits by Randy Bacon

Stories by our Homeless Friends

 

On any given night in the United States an estimated 600,000 people sleep homeless. Award winning photographer and filmmaker, Randy Bacon in conjunction with nonprofits 7 Billion Ones and Gathering Friends for the Homeless started documenting stories from our homeless friends over 5 years ago - to date Randy and his team have collected the stories and portraits of 100's of homeless.  These portraits and stories have culminated in an extensive, powerful body of work that is a major art exhibition titled, "The Road I Call Home”. 

The Road I Call Home is building a new awareness about our relationship to homelessness and to each other.  It gives a powerful voice to the voiceless and creates conversations that will be an inspiration for people to get involved. THE ROAD I CALL HOME challenges each viewer, through stunning portrait artwork with raw, authentic stories, to view homelessness with eyes of compassion versus negative judgment - inspiring each viewer to simply acknowledge those in need, trusting that we are all the same, all wanting to love and be loved.

The Road I Call Home began in 2015 and has been exhibited at multiple art museums, galleries and institutions across the nation - thousands upon thousands of people have been impacted by the portraits and stories, creating positive change.  The Road I Call Home exhibition is now going on a national art museum tour starting in 2021 through 2025. 

 

 

 

THE ARTIST - RANDY BACON 

THE ROAD I CALL HOME is the artistic brainchild of Randy Bacon, a multi-award winning, prominent international photographer, filmmaker, public speaker and humanitarian. The exhibit features simple, direct, casual studio portraits that emphasize the beauty, dignity, and integrity of each person - not the stereotypical representation of the homeless. Randy presents their important lives and stories rooted in compassion and belief that, as a community, we can approach homelessness by choosing to see the beauty of each person in front of us - rather than the issues that overwhelm us. 

 

 

THE PORTRAITS

Here are a few of the special people that are part of The Road I Call Home.

 

 

 

THE RESPONSE 

We continue to be blown away by the passionately compassionate response to The Road I Call Home and the ways in which the art and the raw, emotional stories are changing lives and igniting discussion about the topic of homelessness.  We have received countless comments and requests for The Road I Call Home Art Book.  We recognize that these stories need to be told to the world, so we are self publishing a book and we are inviting you to join us in this journey to change the world one story at a time.  

“I didn’t want to like this exhibition. I am one of those people that sees a homeless person on the street and looks the other way. I’ve got to tell you, this changed me. We are all changed.  Really powerful work. I just had to tell you that.”- Mary 

“Our class was really touched by the stories. These people need to be treated as people. They need to get the care that they deserve.”-Nicholas (5th grader)

“I'm homeless  and I just saw the portrait and read the story of Kacy from The Road I Call Home, I'm so grateful to hear his story. Most people don't know what it's like to be homeless and how we are treated by strangers, family and friends. From time to time I get to hear a feel good story of someone who has made it and the encouragement they offer not to give up hope. Thank you for this.” - John (Homeless Individual)

 

We have been asked countless times to publish The Road I Call Home book. 

To do this, we need your help!  

 

The Road I Call Home book will share the artistic portraits and authentic stories of all of our homeless friends with the world.  We have seen the monumental response to The Road I Call Home art exhibition and we feel that a photography art book will give each of these special individuals and their important stories the time that they truly deserve, allowing the viewer to fully experience each individual portrait and story.    

 

OUR PLAN 

  • We will design and print an initial run of 1,000 breathtaking hardcover coffee table photography art books. 
  • The Road I Call Home book will be produced to museum quality art book standards - it will beautifully represent each portrait and each story. 
  • The book will contain over 90 beautiful portraits with the corresponding narrative.
  • Book will be oversized at approximately 10" x 10".
  • Estimated completion date Spring 2021. 
  • We will make books available on our website for purchase.  
  • We are offering 10 reward levels for backers in a range of options.

(Our designers are working on finalizing cover and layout) 

 

WHAT WILL THE MONEY GO TOWARD? 

Eighty percent of our $26,000 goal is to cover the initial print run and shipping of 1,000 books.  Additional expenses include design and marketing for the book. We are very passionate and determined to publish this book, but we cannot self publish without a robust funding effort.  In addition to the campaign, we are seeking private donations.  If you believe in the power of story and the message behind The Road I Call Home as much as we do, and want to contribute more than any of the levels listed here, please reach out to us. 7 Billion Ones is a non-profit and all direct donations (outside of this crowdfunding campaign) are tax deductible.  

Through  the sales of The Road I Call Home book, Randy Bacon and his non-profit, 7 Billion Ones, will be able to continue to capture stories of our homeless friends.  Proceeds will also support the Road I Call Home Exhibition and efforts to bring this very important project to as many people as we can to share our message that each and every person on this earth deserves dignity, respect, and love.  

Donation Levels 

$5 or more “Compassionate Heart”

  • Good karma and virtual hugs

$25 or more “Kindness Rocks” 

  • Acknowledgement on our websites 
  • 1- 16x20 exhibition poster from The Road I Call Home signed by artist Randy Bacon. 

 $75.00 or more “Book Club”

  • 1 Copy of the book signed by artist Randy Bacon
  • Acknowledgement on our websites

$100 or More “Super Star Supporter” 

  • 1 Copy of the book signed by artist Randy Bacon 
  • 1- 16x20 exhibition poster from The Road I Call Home signed by artist Randy Bacon. 
  • Acknowledgement in the book and on our websites

 $200 or more “Super-duper Star Supporter” 

  • 2- Copies of the book signed by artist Randy Bacon 
  • 2- 16x20 exhibition posters from The Road I Call Home signed by artist Randy Bacon
  • 2- 10" x 10" archival museum quality photographs from the exhibit; signed by Randy Bacon 
  • Acknowledgement in the book and on our websites

$300 or more “Story Warrior Supporter” 

  • 3- copies of book signed by artist Randy Bacon
  • 3-16x20 exhibition posters from The Road I Call Home signed by artist Randy Bacon.
  • 3- 10" x 10" archival museum quality photographs from the exhibit; signed by Randy Bacon 
  • Acknowledgement in the book and on our websites 

$500 or more “Friends of the Homeless” 

  • 3- Copies of the book signed by Randy Bacon
  • 3- 20" x 20" archival museum quality photographs from the exhibit, signed by artist Randy Bacon.  Each piece of art comes with the powerful corresponding story of one of our homeless friends. 
  • 1-16x20 exhibition poster from The Road I Call Home signed by artist Randy Bacon. 
  • Acknowledgement in the book and on our websites

$1000 or More  “Cornerstone Supporter” 

  • 3- Copies of the book signed by Randy Bacon
  • 3- 30"x 30" archival museum quality photographs from the exhibit, signed by artist Randy Bacon.  Each piece of art comes with the powerful corresponding story of one of our homeless friends.
  • 1-16x20 exhibition poster from The Road I Call Home signed by artist Randy Bacon.  
  • Acknowledgement in the book and on our websites

$2,500 or More “Executive Sponsorship”

  • 3- Copies of the book signed by artist Randy Bacon 
  • 3-  30"x 30" archival museum quality photographs from the exhibit, signed by artist Randy Bacon.  Each piece of art comes with the powerful corresponding story of one of our homeless friends.
  • 1-16x20 exhibition poster from The Road I Call Home signed by artist Randy Bacon.   
  • Acknowledgement in the book and on our websites 
  • One 1 hour private studio session with the Artist Randy Bacon 
    • Includes $1,000 credit towards the purchase of photographic prints
    • Studio session held at Randy Bacon Studio and Gallery in Springfield, MO 

$5,000 or More “Executive Producer” 

  • 3- Copies of the book signed by artist Randy Bacon 
  • 3-  30"x 30" archival museum quality photographs from the exhibit, signed by artist Randy Bacon.  Each piece of art comes with the powerful corresponding story of one of our homeless friends.
  • 1-16x20 exhibition poster from The Road I Call Home signed by artist Randy Bacon.   
  • Acknowledgement in the book and on our websites 
  • One 2 hour private studio session with the Artist Randy Bacon 
    • Includes $2,500 credit towards the purchase of photographic prints 
    • Studio session held at Randy Bacon Studio and Gallery in Springfield, MO

Important Links for Reference: 

The Road I Call Home

Randy Bacon

7 Billion Ones

story:
In Breve

Questa campagna serve a finanziare la miglior guida su Youtube sulla fotografia a pellicola, per tutti coloro che intendono approcciarsi a questo genere di fotografia.

Chi sono

Mi chiamo Davide e sono un fotografo/filmmaker/content creator italiano.

Su Youtube documento il mio percorso in questo mondo, puoi trovare tutti i miei link qua!

Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/pirots

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/pirotsphotos/

Portfolio:  https://www.pirots.com

L'idea

La maggior parte dei miei lavori si è sempre svolto in digitale, ma riprendere in mano la fotografia a pellicola è stata una svolta per la mia fotografia.

C'è qualcosa di magico nell'attesa dei tuoi scatti, nei toni, nell'esperienza che la fotografia a pellicola può restituirti. L'attesa del risultato e l'incertezza son quegli elementi che fanno accrescere esponenzialmente il valore dei tuoi scatti.

I gap che intercorrono tra una foto e l'altra, potendo scattare meno, vengono poi riempiti dai propri ricordi, è lo strumento analogico numero 1 per la nostalgia.

Da quando ho iniziato a condividere la mia esperienza sulla fotografia a pellicola, ho ricevuto diverse domande su tutti gli aspetti di questo mondo fotografico, così nasce questa guida.

Cosa otterrai

La guida definitiva alla fotografia a pellicola è una guida sia per beginners, che per avanzati che vogliono approfondire certi aspetti di questo mondo, in cui vi spiego tutto dalle basi, allo scatto, allo sviluppo fino al prodotto finale.

Non essendo il maggiore esperto di fotografia a pellicola di questo mondo, nel video avrò anche ospiti speciali e diverse sorprese che vedrete in futuro.

La guida verrà realizzata in qualsiasi caso, ma volendo fare un prodotto di qualità molto elevata mi piacerebbe poter avere un budget più consistente da poter investire in risorse, eventuali premi per un giveaway a sfondo pellicola, animazioni più complesse e molto altro ancora.

Ed è per questo che nasce la campagna su Indiegogo.

Il video non è a scopo di lucro, tutto ciò che verrà ricavato sarà utilizzato per questo progetto e/o per supportare il canale.

Altri modi in cui puoi contribuire

Stiamo vivendo un periodo molto delicato e donare per un progetto può non essere la tua prima priorità. Intanto apprezzo moltissimo anche solo la considerazione di questo progetto ed aver letto fino a qua.

Nel caso voleste supportare il progetto senza donare vi basterà condividere il video e la campagna ai chiunque pensiate possa essere interessato e magari condividerla nelle storie taggandomi @pirotsphotos

Grazie mille, un abbraccio virtuale.

Davide.

story:
About the Project

Skuzi - a Photo Essay of Maltese Life will celebrate Maltese culture and daily life. 

This project will capture moments that reflect the island country’s beauty by sharing the lives of the fishermen, shopkeepers, religious leaders, and others that give the Mediterranean archipelago its character.

This project will be conducted with the guidance and support of Expeditions, Research in Applied Anthropology, and the Off the Beaten Track Field School (https://www.xpeditions.be). This is the longest standing cultural anthropology field school in the world. 

The photos taken for this book will contribute to a greater research question centered on public responses to being photographed and willingness to engage with strangers. As a street photographer, I have been met with both complete open willingness to engage with me when I strike up a conversation with a camera in hand and total apprehension or aggression. I am interested in researching how this same act is greeted in a country like Malta. The project is titled skuzi because it is the Maltese word for ‘excuse me.’ A phrase that I will consistently use to begin my interactions with people in the community.

 

What You Get & My Experience

Your trust. Having a new favorite coffee table book, framed photo, or high-five is a big deal these days. The photos I will be taking and the subsequent project I will be producing requires your trust to make them engaging, intimate, and interesting. How do you know that will happen?

You can know this by looking through my past work on my website (https://www.danlampmann.com) and on my Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/danlampmann/). The focus of my photography is and has always been to capture true moments and tell real stories. Whether it be sitting with folks experiencing homelessness in Pittsburgh to speaking with a foreman at a construction site in Philadelphia to sitting down with world-renowned sculptor Thaddeus Mosley, I focus on people, their stories, and the incredible lives of the strangers that we pass each day.

I don't misrepresent, I contextualize and share the stories I'm told. That is what you will get when you support this project with a financial donation. That is what I promise.

 

Why Malta?

Malta is an incredible country with a complicated and constantly developing culture because of the relationship between traditional values and Western influences. It's a densely populated island that is not Italian, nor English, but distinctly Maltese.

The island sits in the Mediterranean Sea, just South of Italy and Sicily, Northeast of Tunisia, and directly North of Libya. 

Malta's location and history have granted it a unique religious and cultural heritage. It only recently achieved independence in 1964 and joined the European Union in 2004. 

This is a culture I believe should be more widely known about and I hope that through my work, I will be able to share its culture with more people.

 

Risks & Challenges

This is my first photography book, and it's in another country and I'm asking for a lot of support. It's a risky move. But here's the thing, with risk comes opportunity. A fellow photographer and cultural anthropologist, Joshua Cogan recently told me this: "you can either hang out here and wait for someone to discover you or you can go do something." So, I decided to go do something.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate, there are other ways to support! You can:

  1. Share this link on social media with a personal endorsement. Your support means the world.
  2. Send me any links or ideas for grants and scholarships you know of that you feel this project is perfect for.
  3. Connect me to your Maltese friends! I am currently trying to read, listen, watch, as much as I can to learn about Maltese culture prior to my trip in June and being able to speak to someone from Malta would aid my research greatly.

story:
The Project:

There is a place where the distinction between waking life and dreaming life is blurred. A place where people gather to create a model of a new world, a world they only dream about. In this new world, creativity is limitless and there is absolute freedom of expression. People are unafraid to connect with one another. Upon meeting there is immediate affection, there is eye contact. People experience each other's energy and recognize each other's spirits. They encourage one another toward personal growth in mind, body, and spirit. Societal boundaries are broken. In this place the sacred is respected and celebrated. 

In May of 2014, I experienced my first Transformational Festival, Lightning In A Bottle. Some friends of mine had an installation at this festival, and they brought me on the team to photograph their project. Initially, I thought this was going to be like any other music festival I had attended in the past. Except, it featured electronic music. What I found, instead, was a safe and creative environment for an emerging culture to thrive; a culture dedicated to expanding human awareness by cultivating love in our relationships with each other, ourselves, and our environment. People of this culture see each other as mirror reflections of themselves. Transformational Festivals are immersive, participatory realities that inspire positive change within the participants. 

Creating A Dream is my effort to document a new culture that illuminates hope, creativity, joy, and love. Through still photographs and short films, I invite the viewer to experience these festivals and people the way I experience them. 



What I Need & What You Get:

I am requesting $10,000 in order to finish shooting Creating A Dream. The money goes directly toward travel, equipment, admission to the festivals (if I cannot retrieve a media pass), printing supplies, promotional materials to send to publishers, food, and camping gear. The vision is to publish Creating A Dream as a book. The book will include 20-40 photographs along with writings, such as quotes from festival participants and my own thoughts and experiences. The book release will be an interactive experience. The prints will be on display amongst music, dancers, performers, healers, and more... I want to bring the transformational festival experience to the event! 

To do all of this, I need your help. I do not currently bring in enough income to fund this project alone. So here I am, asking for help to make Creating A Dream a reality. I need this money in order to finish shooting the project, and to shop it out to book publishers!

In exchange for your donations, there will be perks! Such perks include limited edition prints, an inside look into the project, signed copies of the book, hand-picked treasures from my travels, and much more! I would LOVE for you to join me in this journey.



The Festivals:

As of right now, the itinerary is as follows:

  • Lucidity Festival: April 10-12 (Santa Barbara, CA)
  • Joshua Tree Music Festival: May 14-17 (Joshua Tree, CA)
  • Lightning In A Bottle: May 21-25 (Bradley, CA)
  • Bonnaroo: June 11-14 (Manchester, TN)
  • Electric Forest: June 25-28 (Rothbury, MI)
  • Burning Man: Aug 20 - Sept 7 (Black Rock Desert, NV)
  • Symbiosis Gathering: Sept 17-20 (Oakdale, CA)

How I Feel About Photography:

I started taking photographs when I was ten years old. From that moment on it has always felt right to be looking at my world through a lens, because that is how I see things: cinematically. In the beginning of my relationship with photography, I felt that I was trying so hard to take “good photos” using the tools I had learned in school to properly compose/expose the image. Then I fell in love with the work of Henri Cartier-Bresson, and suddenly learned that there is no secret to taking good photos. You simply have to look. That is when I took all the “rules” I had been taught and threw them out the window, letting my eyes guide me towards beauty.

To look at my photographs is to look at my Self. To feel my energy, see the magic that I see in life, get inside my mind, eyes, and heart. Taking photographs is meditative. I must be completely present, focusing all energy and love in to the moment, so when I click that shutter I have captured a moment in time that has feeling. Richard Avedon once said that “a photograph is the death of a moment.” When you look at a photograph you are literally looking at the death of that moment. It was there, for that fraction of a second... and will never be again. But here is the proof that moment existed, and here is how I experienced that moment. The magic of photography continues to amaze me every time I see a beautiful image. When you look at my photograph, the light that shines in me radiates to you. It is this way with all forms of art, which is why art is so important. Life is about connecting with everyone and everything, and art is a link. 

See through my eyes and feel my spirit.


Photo: Here I am overlooking Coachella Valley in California. This was taken last year while in between festivals when I started Creating A Dream. Photo by Hannah Theim.


Other Ways You Can Help!:

If it's impossible for you to donate, then please, please, PLEASE share this project on social media. The more eyes on this project there are, the more support I'll receive. Please help me in shining the light on a culture that inspires us to embrace our own inner light, to shine on the world.

With all of my heart, thank you.

-Bonnie Blue Britt

story:
SUPPOSE THAT ONE DAY YOU WANTED TO TALK WITH SOMEONE WHO IS IMPORTANT TO YOU WHO PASSED AWAY

DAY OF THE DEAD - A human celebration of life - is a contemporary artistic experience which will allow you to go deep inside of a never told story about this annual ritual subscribed in 2008 to the UNESCO intangible cultural heritage list. 

This simple question may be the main idea to peer inside one of the most world´s widely known cultural celebrations.  I find that most of the time, people only can see the surface of this amazing event. During the last 6 months I have been working to produce a contemporary photographic artwork to let the world know why this Mexican celebration is an important human cultural heritage.

CELEBRATING LIFE TROUGH ART

A very pure and clear message for those who have lost a friend, brother, sister, child, or parent to understand the deep vision about a celebration of life and honor to dead ones.

I will be using different artistic techniques such as: Art Installation, body paint, motion photography, light painting and the traditional materials used in this ritual to compose and capture a very unique and contemporary photographic collection, sharing it trough a large scale outdoor fine art exhibition in San Miguel de Allende in November 2015. 

FEAR, LOVE, SADNESS, JOY, ANGER, PEACE

I believe that life is something awesome, but sometimes it's hard to face our own path in life. The Day of The Dead celebration offers something really important for every human’s life and I want to help to understand and share it in several ways of art. We are working to make this happen in four artistic expressions, created with the support of a great team of people conformed by Mexican and international artists, professional consulters, designers, activist and networkers.  

EXPRESSION#1

We will set up  a human installation experience, In a local event, in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico. We’ll produce a unique fine art photographic footage and capture “THE DAY OF THE DEAD EMOTIONS” to create the new large scale collection. Using human body models, a professional team of body painters, illumination staff, digital film equipment and artistic installation design.

 EXPRESSION#2

We will film during the human installation event  to make a short movie of theTHE DAY OF THE DEAD EMOTIONS including a “making of” video that we’ll share this amazing human experiencearound the world on our social networks like vimeo and youtube, A neverbefore seenscenario of this celebration.

 When?

Expression #1 and #2, will take place in San Miguel de Allende at the same time in the same place in October 18, 2015. Our first Goal to make it happen: $3,200 USD

 EXPRESSION#3

Set up the ten 4x7 feet large scale photos in a stunning outdoor exhibition DAY OF THE DEAD EMOTIONS in a special venue in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico. And share it with visitors from all over the world.November 1st, 2015. 

Our second Goal to make it happen: $3,000 USD 


EXPRESSION#4

4.- Printing the first 200 edition book with the photographic footage to share  ten years of one life in a deep dive into  the artistic and cultural universe around the Day of The Dead in Michoacán, the state where this celebration remains alive and deeply rooted with the authentic prehispanic ritual.

 Our third Goal to make it happen: $2,700 USD

When? 

This artwork piece will be ready to publishing in December 15, and delivery approximate in February or earlier is you choose an express delivery company.


VITAL ENERGY TO WORK 

You may agree this is something huge and you are right.  We are working with different professional and experienced teams to reach our goals. We believe in the value of the human work and we are respecting the fees that collaborator teams are asking to keep all on track and doing well.  We are confident in the results of this never before done special artwork, and the quality that we will offer to our supporters and to thousands of people; this is the total price of each expression:

Expression #1  $1,500 

Expression #2  $1,700

Expression #3  $3,000 

Expression #4  $2,700

PLUS INDIEGOGO, PAYPAL AND MONEY EXCHANGE FEES 10%

TOTAL: $9,790 USD


TAKE A LOOK BEYOND THE FOG WALL AND LET SHINE YOUR IMAGINATION.

Where does the money go? This is a complete journey and there is a talented team behind of it. Support us and you will get exclusive details and updates about the production of every different expression; all the each contributors will receive a newsletter every week to keep you in the light.  You also can stay connected to Jesus Alexandre Arts facebook page and be updated about events, photos, special presentations and how we are creating a stunning exhibition with your support and spirit of contribution.
What we need and what you get.

We want to spread an international and eclectic way to see this amazing cultural event and share with the world a beautiful way to celebrate life. To reach every artistic expression goal we need to pay the production fees of each event and the support team. Contribute to this campaign and you will get an original piece of this fine and unique artwork. Contribute more and receive the coffee table photo book and allow yourself or someone important for you to get a luminiscent view of life.

The Mysterious Photo Index:

This is a pre-sale of the new photographic artwork collection that will be shot in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico on October 18 during a Human Installation event directed by Jesus Alexandre. The Mysterious Photo Index will be the best artistic photographic work selected so far by the artist.  October 24, 2015 our contributor will  receive  an email titled THE MYSTERIOS PHOTO INDEX  to choose the printed photo they want. Also you can see part of the Day of The Dead Origins Photo Index here.

THE TEAM, A MULTICULTURAL MOVEMENT

We are so proud to work with a great Mexican and international team and network, and this network is growing up exponentially because we believe in the talent and spirit of the people who is around us working, and inspiring to grow together.

Join us in this Journey, we will be glad to have you visit our web page www.jesusalexandre.com to take a look about this campaign, team members, information about the artist, and the spirit of Michoacan foundation. 

AND REMEMBER IF YOU CAN´T CONTRIBUTE MONEY, YOU CAN HELP US WITH YOUR SPIRIT OF COLLABORATION SHARING THIS CAMPAIGN WITH THE PEOPLE THAT YOU KNOW COULD BE INTERESTED IN THE DAY OF THE DEAD, SKULL FANS, THANATOLOGISTS, ANTHROPOLOGISTS,  ART COLLECTORS,PHOTOGRAPHERS OR SIMPLY SOMEONE WHO NEEDS TO LET GO THE PAST AND ENJOY THE PRESENT.  

THANK YOU!

 JSUS ALXNDRE
