story:
Bacite se iz aviona i uljepšajte naš projekt

Short Summary

We are a group of enthusiasts interested in skydiving, photography,  traveling and exploring, gathered in Airclub Cumulus - Opatija - Croatia.

Our campaign aims to connect  beauty of landscapes with skydiving trough artistic photography and bring it closer to people around the world who do not have the opportunity to see the world from skydivers perspective.

Our wish and goal is to take loads of attractive photographs of our activities on beautiful landscapes of Croatia, to organize and coordinate group of 30 skydivers which will perform those jumps on 20 locations and to have lots of fun along the way. Please, help us to achieve that :)

We have a lot of experience organizing  this sort of events. We started in 2009 when we first organized Skydive Photo Contest  on island Lošinj. Given it was a big success we decided to repeat it and we have been organizing it since. Later on we decided to try other locations such as Opatija and Ičići as well.. This year we would like to spread this project on many other locations, and that is why we need a bit more subventions.

What We Need & What You Get

We need 30 USD to cover expenses for one 'jump ticket' (airplane, fuel and airport charges). Our goal is to cover group of 30 skydivers to perform 2 jumps at each of 20 locations, (Vrsar, Medulin, Unije, Lošinj, Krk, Rab, Pag, Zadar, Hvar, Brač, Vis, Dubrovnik, Nikšić, Sinj, Otočac, Bihać, Zagreb, Varaždin, Osijek and Borovo airfields).

Through simple calculation (33,75 USD x 30 skydivers x 2 jumps x 20 locations) we get required budget of 40.500 USD

For your donations we are happy to offer you rights for using our aerial landscape photography. We can  jump with some special messages for your friends, fans or customers on our clothes or we can put your stickers on our airplane during  this project as well.

Unfortunately, we can not offer you to jump with us because this kind of perk is not allowed, but if you are qualified skydiver, you can become one of our team member.

The Impact

This project is important and beneficial to many because it will help:

  • young skydivers to increase the skills and gain experience
  • spread information about tourist locations which are not yet disocvered by many people, yet very beautiful
  • photographs taken will be keept as historical document

Your support will enable us to reduce the price of skydiving jumps and thereby increase the number of jumps. Also, we will get the opportunity to perform more jumps on several beautiful locations, and of course that will allow us to take more beautiful photographs.

Risks & Challenges

We are skydivers, and we know a lot about the risk. Also, we know a lot about reducing the risk and our goal is to have fun and be safe and we will take all percautionary meassures to make sure that this project runs smoothly. To ensure that, we have Civil Aviation Agency which is involved in organizing the project. Its job is to resolve and eliminate possible issues and risks and give us permissions for air activities.

Our only challenge are finances, because Skydive Photo Contest tour which we want to organize on 20 locations requires enough financial capabilities to cover airplane, fuel and airport expenses. All other expenses will be covered by skydivers themselves.

Here we will present few risks and how we plan to  solve it:

  • Permissions from Airspace control - we need 7 to 10 days to get approval; approvals for some of the locations we already have for 3 month period
  • Permissions from Civil Aviation Authorities - we need few days to get approval which again, depends on Airspace control approval; valid airplane documents and pilot documents, valid insurance for airplane and parachutes. (We do have all required documents).
  • Meteorological situation is unfortunately something we have no control of, but we have lot of forecast information and we can plan and reschedule our activities. Our time frame allow us to be flexible.
  • In case that we do not have 30 skydivers available for some of the location, we can easily reduce number of jumps on some location and increase it on another where we have enough
  • Should there be some technical problem occurred with the airplane, we have option to rent other airplane.

If we don't reach planned funds, we will reduce number of skydivers, or number of jumps, or reduce some of the locations.

If we collect more funds than planned, we will invest them in purchase of safety equipment for young skydivers.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to help us by donating, please help us by making information about this project and information about the possibilities of donating this project available to your friends and acquaintances, especially those acquaintances who are engaged in skydiving, aviation, yachting, landcruising; those acquaintances who love to travel and explore.

skydiving, photography,  traveling and exploring, gathered in Airclub
Cumulus - Opatija - Croatia.
Our campaign aims to connect  beauty of
landscapes with skydiving trough artistic photography and bring it closer to
people around the world who do not have the opportunity to see the world from
skydivers perspective.
Our
wish and goal is to take loads of attractive photographs of our activities on
beautiful landscapes of Croatia, to organize and coordinate group of 30
skydivers which will perform those jumps on 20 locations and to have lots of
fun along the way. Please, help us to achieve that :)
We have a lot of experience organizing  this sort of events. We started in 2009 when
we first organized Skydive Photo Contest 
on island Lošinj. Given it was a big success we decided to repeat it and
we have been organizing it since. Later on we decided to try other locations
such as Opatija and Ičići as well.. This year we would like to spread this

story:
Dear you,

Let me introduce myself. I am Özümcan Akın, a senior undergrad at Boğaziçi University. I am currently majoring in Translation and Interpreting Studies, also an amateur photographer and film director. I am enrolled in my university's Film Studies Certification Program where I am expanding my knowledge about film and the art of cinema. In the last a few years I have entirely exposed myself to cinema and photography. As a result of this long period of devotion, I have come up with this idea of a photography exhibition on which my friend Efe Alparslan Bütüner agreed to help. To make my dream a reality, I need your support!

Here is the scope and aim of my exhibition project:

We will take 10 portrait photographs of 10 people chosen from diverse strata of society. Every photograph will tell a different story: The first one will be focusing on our model's actual self. To achieve this level of personal output, I have worked with a couple of professional psychologists to devise questions aimed to elicit our models' past experiences which would have a definitive impact on their personality. After talking about them, we will take the first photograph. The remaining nine photographs will be taken within the 2-month period on days of our choice, following the initiation of our project. The final result with all ten photographs superimposed with a unique physical technique will reflect how the self is affected and shaped after a set of just nine random events in a person's life.

Thus, when you visit our exhibition, we will be able to give you the opportunity to see the traces of various social, political and economic events left on our models' faces and observe recent history through a more sincere perspective. The idea behind this project is to draw people's attention to the lack of social communication within the last decade as we tend more to create a virtual reality with our mobile devices than actually live in our collective reality with face-to-face interactions.

Modern day individuals have made it a habit to confine the social, political and economic impacts of events surrounding all of us within a 4-5 inch screen. Consequently, these individuals can only observe the effects of these events on themselves or others they keep in close proximity. Our exhibition will make it possible for seeing what has been whittled away from or added on to our models' visages.

We strongly believe that our project will form new sociological, psychological and artistic ways of looking at the art of photography. In order for us to complete our exhibition we need 2.000 USD to rent a photography studio, have a custom designed lighting built, purchase a light meter, have our exhibition poster designed, print promotional banners and flyers, print our photographs on A2-size paper and to have one hundred custom designed stands to display our photographs.

With your invaluable support, we can open this exhibition we have been painstakingly designing and planning, and provide a more sincere perspective for all of us to actually look at what is happening around us!

Our most sincere thanks for your contribution,
Özümcan and Efe

story:
American Fraternity

Hi, I'm Andrew Moisey.  I spent 7 years photographing college fraternity life at the University of California, Berkeley.  Now I'm teaming with a nonprofit publisher, Daylight Books, to publish the first photo book about what really happens inside fraternities and the influence they wield in American power.  

American Fraternity arrives as we ponder the rise of Trump and the fall of Harvey Weinstein and others, and wonder why so many male leaders have such reckless and chauvinistic behavior in their past.  American Fraternity shows us the true conditions under which most government and industry leaders--presidents, senators, justices, CEOs--in modern American history, not to mention millions of American fathers and sons, graduated from being boys to men.  

Help bring forth the first book of photographs about fraternities.  American Fraternity can change the way we see the history of the United States.  Fraternities are the most powerful forgotten force in American culture and your contribution will bring them to the forefront of our current national conversations.

What Will American Fraternity Be Like?

American Fraternity will appear as an old ritual book with photographs. The text in fact comes from a real decaying ritual manual from a prominent national fraternity. Seventy-five percent of modern U.S. presidents, senators, justices, and executives have taken arcane oaths of chivalry and allegiance like those it contains. Six decades of dripping ceremonial wax stain its pages like blood. It is filled with dark power.

The book is soft and leather-bound and appears to be the property of a college fraternity called “Psi Rho.” As we turn the pages, we see the rituals, the historic imagery, and the raw, intimate photographs of young men ecstatically breaking their chivalric oaths.  Throughout, American Fraternity lists the many US presidents, cabinet members, Senators and Representatives, Supreme Court justices, CEOs, bishops of the church, and college presidents in fraternities. We begin to see fraternity men - for the last hundred and fifty years - as the planted seeds of American leadership.

Three essays will appear as afterwords to the photographs and text: one by historian Nicholas Syrett, author of The Company He Keeps: A History of White College Fraternities; another by novelist and essayist Cynthia Robinson, author of the new novel Birds of Wonder; and a third, a real research paper about "Psi Rho" written by one of its members for a cultural anthropology class.

 

 

What Your Contribution Pays For

Publishing photography books is very expensive.  Your contribution permits the manufacture and distribution of American Fraternity, facilitated by Daylight Books.  Due to Daylight's nonprofit status, any contribution you make is tax-deductible.

  • I need to raise $17,000 to guarantee American Fraternity's publication.
  • $75 donation receives an autographed copy of the book.
  • $200 donation receives an autographed book and a signed, vintage 11x14 fiber-based gelatin silver print.
  • $400 donation receives an autographed book and a signed, vintage 20x24 fiber-based gelatin silver print.
  • $1000 donation receives an autographed book and a handmade walnut-framed 13x19 signed print from the book.

story:
SHORT SUMMARY

Amerasians in the Philippines have longed for help since their abandonment, desperately seeking societal acceptance in the Philippines and legal recognition by the U.S. government. These children suffer mockery, racism, discrimination, and self-identity issues. Labeled often incorrectly - as "half dollar", "souvenir babies" - many live in poverty and stigma in an ultra-conservative Catholic society. Yet, to this day, both governments have largely ignored their pleas for help. Moved by their heart-wrenching stories and frustrated by their political invisibility, Enrico Dungca is compelled to document the faces and stories of these Amerasians, in the hope that more people around the world will learn of their struggle.

What We Need & What You Get

The funds raised will go to the book production, printing, editing, and design costs. With your support and contribution, you will get our sincerest gratitude, social media shout outs, your name on the website, unframed beautiful and rich black and white prints, and with your generous contribution, your name may be mentioned in the "supporters" page plus a signed copy of the book. 

The Impact

Your contribution will help in raising awareness about the plight of the Filipino Amerasians, their struggle for hope, call for help and political and social recognition by the U.S. Government. 

Other Ways You Can Help

It's understandable that financial situation could be tough at this time but by sharing this campaign to your family, friends, relatives, co-workers, it's more than appreciated. Thank you for sharing the link.

story:
Summary

Ranchlands is a photo documentary project that follows the Phillips family of Colorado over two years. The Phillips family owns and manages several large ranches in Colorado and New Mexico and have been ranching for five generations. They practice traditional ranching methods while embracing some modern methods that stress conservation and responsible grazing management to preserve the local ecosystem. With current food demands and globalization, the Phillips family's lifestyle and culture are slowly vanishing, replaced by big box cattle production. This culture is an integral part of the American identity. Over the two year period, I am following the Phillips family during their day-to-day routines. From mundane chores to branding and moving cattle.  The final product will be a 100-page, hardcover book divided into seasons with commentary by Duke Phillips III, the ranch hands, and myself.

Impact

Ranching is a classic way of American life. Due to population growth and the increased need for food in America and around the world, traditional ranches are being replaced by warehouse-style cattle yards. The traditional ranching lifestyle is slowly disappearing and will likely change dramatically over the next few decades. This documentary photo book aims to preserve a part of our nation's history and chronicle how Ranchlands applies modern, science-based management methods and ambitious conservation programs to encourage large-scale preservation and restoration of our natural resources.

Fundraising Goals

  • I am self-publishing this book and am seeking help with publishing costs. The funding for time, travel, and gear necessary to finish this project has already been obtained and 75% of the photography has been completed.
  • I am looking for $15,000 to help cover the costs of hardcover book printing containing 100 pages for 300 copies.
  • All funds will go directly to book printing. All other costs for the project I am covering myself.

Risks & Challenges

As I have just passed the halfway point in this project, the risks are becoming fewer. As I travel most of the summer season for work, I have chosen to live on the ranch this summer to eliminate additional time constraints. I will be immersed in the ranch life and free to photograph on a day-to-day basis in order to obtain the remaining images necessary to complete the project.  

My gear is insured, I have back-ups, and can get replacements without having to abandon the project. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please spread the word to family and friends.
  • Share on social media.

Help get the word out, every little bit helps!

Thank you so much for your generous contribution.

story:
BACKGROUND

My name is Brad. I'm a photographer and filmmaker from Toronto, Canada. 

I've always had a deep love for the road. It's an indescribable feeling - something that is rooted in peace, catharsis, liberation, excitement and a myriad of other headspaces. Being behind the wheel is one of my favourite places on earth, it's simultaneous simplicity and unpredictability are feelings that I find myself constantly chasing. I'm a documentarian at heart and honesty is something that I value more than anything within my work. In a world of likes and internet auras, A Moving Document will standout as a barebones, dirty and honest investigation of transience and human nature explored through visual and auditory mediums.
 


 

WHERE I'M GOING AND HOW I'M TRAVELLING:

I'll be taking this journey not in a VW bus, but a 2015 Grand Caravan ~ not glamorous, but with a little elbow grease we can turn this thing into a mean van of my dreams.
 


Here's a map of my projected route, spread over 5 months. This will likely change as I find tiny towns and good suggestions throughout my journey, but the heart of it will stay the same:
 


 

A MOVING DOCUMENT:
 

STILL LIFE

ZINE: FACES

FACES IS PART 1/3 OF A MOVING DOCUMENT

FACES began as a concept in 2017 when I travelled throughout Australia, Sri Lanka, The Pacific Northwest and Northern Canada. I had a very simple approach: take photos and record anecdotes of the people I met. In my notes I answered questions like how was I feeling, what was the moment before, what did they say, who were they?

I embark on this years adventure to gather more faces and stories. 

This zine will be printed on a high-quality paper stock and include approximately 150 pages of colour and monochromatic photography. This book will be completed in late 2018. 

~~~~

AUDITORY

PODCAST: THE ROAD

THE ROAD IS PART 2/3 OF A MOVING DOCUMENT

The Road is a podcast that will take place behind my steering wheel and through the phone lines. I'll be chatting with people from all different walks of life who travel, live nomadically and whose head opens up when the road's in front of them.

The goal is to discuss the headspaces and ways of life of people who enjoy plopping down behind the wheel - this will include anyone from folks who commute for work everyday to truck drivers to van lifers to chronic travellers. The goal of the discussion is to provide clarity, understanding and a forum for curious listeners who also think voraciously while they're behind the wheel. By featuring a vastly different group of people, I'm aiming to spotlight obscure ways of life and thought processes. As much as this is a project centred around travel, the conversation will be relevant to everyone; the bread n' butter of this podcast is about humanity in general.

My goal is to record every interview while I'm driving myself to help ideas flow and the discussion to remain honest in it's production. 

~~~~

MOVING IMAGE

DOC: COGS AND WHEELS

COGS AND WHEELS IS PART 3/3 OF A MOVING DOCUMENT

Cogs and Wheels (working title) will be a 10-15 minute documentary that features people, places, thoughts and all of the encounters from my experience living out of my van for five months. 

Cogs and Wheels will be a high-energy experience discussing the 'busy trap' and the life that we all strive for: finding that feeling of belonging, happiness and navigating what it means to be human. Interviews will take place in bars at 3am, my van in the early morning, on mountainsides and in coffee shops. This is a scrappy film, with a scrappy message. As I'm writing this I have no idea WHO will be in it, or WHAT they're going to talk about, which excites me. 

I'm also planning on using elements from both THE ROAD and FACES to put this film together. 

A MOVING DOCUMENT is a multi-medium project that will exist in flux and exist in cohesion. Each arm of the project will work together to make a final, exciting, piece of work.
 

WHERE THE FUNDS ARE GOING:


I've spent loads of time meticulously budgeting my next year, accounting for each and every potential cost I will incur. I've been working like crazy freelancin' and part time jobbin' to make this trip happen. Your gracious contribution will help me get the final few dollars I need to turn this concept into reality.

I've got lots of interesting perks up for grabs to help fund this project. Prints, Zines, Mystery Boxes, Point n Shoots and more! Any contribution is appreciated ~ there's perks as low as $5 and as high as $800, everything helps. If you live in the Toronto area, let me know, and I'll give you back the money for shipping when I give you the perk!
1) 15% / Analogue Related Costs ~ A large chunk of my photography work is shot with 35mm film. Film has a special quality to it that captures the look and energy I desire but costs a decent penny for purchase and processing. This percentage will also cover costs related to Super 8 film purchase and processing.

2) 30% / Zine Related ~ This portion of the funds will help FACES be produced as a print object, shipped worldwide and have a proper launch to ensure success.

3) 10% / Van Related ~ I just need a couple more bucks outside my wallet to really spruce this thing up and make it fully liveable. This money will help me outfit the van with the proper storage compartments, solar panel installation and a few internal renovations.

4) 5% / Podcast Related ~ Fortunately I already have the equipment necessary to work on THE ROAD. This portion will help me with any costs related to distribution.

5) 15% / Documentary Related ~ In order to make this film looking amazing I'll need to reach out to friends to help with certain elements like title design, motion graphic work, colour grading etc. This will help me fund that portion of the costs.

6) 10% / Living Costs ~ I'm definitely going to have to eat to make this project happen. This will help me cover both food and fuel costs while I'm on the road.

7) 15% / Contingency ~ Things go wrong and Things go right. Oftentimes both are unpredictable. This money will help me cover any other miscellaneous costs that I'm not expecting: car parts, unexpected fuel costs, a broken down laptop, WHO KNOWS.

~~~~~~

VERY EXCITED TO TAKE THIS PROJECT OUT OF MY BRAIN AND INTO THE WORLD!

THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR THE SUPPORT.
YOU CAN FIND ME ONLINE HERE:

www.goldshoots.xyz
instagram.com/goldshoots
story_txt:
BACKGROUNDMy name is Brad. I'm a photographer and filmmaker from Toronto, Canada. I've always had a deep love for the road. It's an indescribable feeling - something that is rooted in peace, catharsis, liberation, excitement and a myriad of other headspaces. Being behind the wheel is one of my favourite places on earth, it's simultaneous simplicity and unpredictability are feelings that I find myself constantly chasing. I'm a documentarian at heart and honesty is something that I value more than anything within my work. In a world of likes and internet auras, A Moving Document will standout as a barebones, dirty and honest investigation of transience and human nature explored through visual and auditory mediums.  WHERE I'M GOING AND HOW I'M TRAVELLING:I'll be taking this journey not in a VW bus, but a 2015 Grand Caravan ~ not glamorous, but with a little elbow grease we can turn this thing into a mean van of my dreams. Here's a map of my projected route, spread over 5 months. This will likely change as I find tiny towns and good suggestions throughout my journey, but the heart of it will stay the same:  
A MOVING DOCUMENT: STILL LIFEZINE: FACESFACES IS PART 1/3 OF A MOVING DOCUMENTFACES began as a concept in 2017 when I travelled throughout Australia, Sri Lanka, The Pacific Northwest and Northern Canada. I had a very simple approach: take photos and record anecdotes of the people I met. In my notes I answered questions like how was I feeling, what was the moment before, what did they say, who were they?I embark on this years adventure to gather more faces and stories. This zine will be printed on a high-quality paper stock and include approximately 150 pages of colour and monochromatic photography. This book will be completed in late 2018. ~~~~AUDITORYPODCAST: THE ROADTHE ROAD IS PART 2/3 OF A MOVING DOCUMENTThe Road is a podcast that will take place behind my steering wheel and through the phone lines. I'll be chatting with people from all different walks of life who travel, live nomadically and whose head opens up when the road's in front of them.The goal is to discuss the headspaces and ways of life of people who enjoy plopping down behind the wheel - this will include anyone from folks who commute for work everyday to truck drivers to van lifers to chronic travellers. The goal of the discussion is to provide clarity, understanding and a forum for curious listeners who also think voraciously while they're behind the wheel. By featuring a vastly different group of people, I'm aiming to spotlight obscure ways of life and thought processes. As much as this is a project centred around travel, the conversation will be relevant to everyone; the bread n' butter of this podcast is about humanity in general.My goal is to record every interview while I'm driving myself to help ideas flow and the discussion to remain honest in it's production. ~~~~MOVING IMAGEDOC: COGS AND WHEELSCOGS AND WHEELS IS PART 3/3 OF A MOVING DOCUMENTCogs and Wheels (working title) will be a 10-15 minute documentary that features people, places, thoughts and all of the encounters from my experience living out of my van for five months. Cogs and Wheels will be a high-energy experience discussing the 'busy trap' and the life that we all strive for: finding that feeling of belonging, happiness and navigating what it means to be human. Interviews will take place in bars at 3am, my van in the early morning, on mountainsides and in coffee shops. This is a scrappy film, with a scrappy message. As I'm writing this I have no idea WHO will be in it, or WHAT they're going to talk about, which excites me. I'm also planning on using elements from both THE ROAD and FACES to put this film together. A MOVING DOCUMENT is a multi-medium project that will exist in flux and exist in cohesion. Each arm of the project will work together to make a final, exciting, piece of work. WHERE THE FUNDS ARE GOING:I've spent loads of time meticulously budgeting my next year, accounting for each and every potential cost I will incur. I've been working like crazy freelancin' and part time jobbin' to make this trip happen. Your gracious contribution will help me get the final few dollars I need to turn this concept into reality.I've got lots of interesting perks up for grabs to help fund this project. Prints, Zines, Mystery Boxes, Point n Shoots and more! Any contribution is appreciated ~ there's perks as low as $5 and as high as $800, everything helps. If you live in the Toronto area, let me know, and I'll give you back the money for shipping when I give you the perk!1) 15% / Analogue Related Costs ~ A large chunk of my photography work is shot with 35mm film. Film has a special quality to it that captures the look and energy I desire but costs a decent penny for purchase and processing. This percentage will also cover costs related to Super 8 film purchase and processing.2) 30% / Zine Related ~ This portion of the funds will help FACES be produced as a print object, shipped worldwide and have a proper launch to ensure success.3) 10% / Van Related ~ I just need a couple more bucks outside my wallet to really spruce this thing up and make it fully liveable. This money will help me outfit the van with the proper storage compartments, solar panel installation and a few internal renovations.4) 5% / Podcast Related ~ Fortunately I already have the equipment necessary to work on THE ROAD. This portion will help me with any costs related to distribution.5) 15% / Documentary Related ~ In order to make this film looking amazing I'll need to reach out to friends to help with certain elements like title design, motion graphic work, colour grading etc. This will help me fund that portion of the costs.6) 10% / Living Costs ~ I'm definitely going to have to eat to make this project happen. This will help me cover both food and fuel costs while I'm on the road.7) 15% / Contingency ~ Things go wrong and Things go right. Oftentimes both are unpredictable. This money will help me cover any other miscellaneous costs that I'm not expecting: car parts, unexpected fuel costs, a broken down laptop, WHO KNOWS.~~~~~~VERY EXCITED TO TAKE THIS PROJECT OUT OF MY BRAIN AND INTO THE WORLD!THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR THE SUPPORT.YOU CAN FIND ME ONLINE HERE:www.goldshoots.xyzinstagram.com/goldshoots

story:
About Forgiving Home

This is about my experience of forgiving where I grew up.  It's not my parents fault that I particularly dislike the place.  I had an unbelievable childhood.  It was my teenage years that made me want to get away so badly.

At 13, I lost my grandfather.  It wasn't unexpected.  He was in his early 90's, had fallen and broken his hip a year earlier, and basically, he never came home.  He lived in a nursing home for the remainder of his life.  I hated that place.  I really regret not spending more time with him in the remainder of his life, but the place he lived, it smelled like death.  It was death.  A day after his passing, I got my period for the first time.

My grandmother was destroyed by his death.  Ended up having a heart attack a few months after his passing from a syndrome called "the broken heart syndrome".  Go figure.  She recovered but was definitely not the same.  Over the next two years, she practically mourned herself to death and on April 17th, my father found her on the floor.  We figure it was another heart attack.  I was at a sleepover the night before.  One of my friends at the sleepover found out about her death before I did, over a text.  So I found out about my grandma... over a text message.  

EXACTLY a week after my grandmother's death, an f-4 tornado hit my town.  I am grateful to be alive.  A tree fell on my room but luckily did not go through the whole house.  20 other trees fell like dominos around our home, but only one fell on our house... on my room.  My neighbor and two of my classmates were killed.  That day was the first time I ever wished I was dead.

Life was a rollercoaster after that.  I went to counseling but, it only taught me how to not talk.  My doctor put me on prozac.  I went from 10mg to 40mg, a full adult dosage, at 15. 

High school was awful.  I wish I liked it.  I wish my good memories were more vivid then the bad memories.  But they aren't, my good memories are hazy; my bad memories are so vivid, like they happened yesterday.  A boy I stupidly thought I was going to marry, broke up with me over a text message, in the middle of my school day.  A girl I thought was one of my closest friends turned on me during a severe mental breakdown, and honestly, I don't blame her.  I was screwed up.  My senior year of high school I remember thinking if I was brave enough, I would jump out the window and hopefully die.  I ended up telling my mother I felt this way (thank God), and the next day I was at the doctors again who finally sent me to a psychiatrist.  I went from Prozac to Celexa which thank God, that medication worked.  I decided to not compete with my high school dance team my senior year because it only made my depression worsen.  Girls are awful.  Their parents are worse.  I still can't believe some of the things those parents said about me, a 17 year old girl, over 30 years younger than they were.  I could care less what those girls said about me, and probably still say about me, it's their parents that hurt me more.  I am so thankful that I had the dance studio, where I had danced since I was 3, to help me fall in love with dance and life again.

College was the best thing to ever happen to me.  5 hours away, away from a place I learned to hate.  My roommates always talked about missing home, but I could never understand.  I missed my parents, but I did not miss home.  

I have lost most of my friends from home, which is completely my fault.  I just distanced myself so much from that place.  I honestly wanted to forget.

I learned forgetting is impossible.  Every time it storms I remember the tornado.  Every time  I sit in my grandfather's reclining chair in my apartment, I remember he fell from that chair which ultimately lead to his death.  Every time I go home, I see my grandparents old house, and am reminded of what was and what is no longer.  Forgetting is impossible, forgiving is not.

So almost 5 years since I graduated high school, finally, I am learning to forgive home.

What We Need & What You Get:

I can not do this alone, this is why I need YOUR help.  

  • My goal is $2,700 raised by May 19. 
  • I don't want to leave you with nothing, that's why once you contribute you could receive a poster from the event, a printed photograph from the exhibition, a thank you note, recognition at the exhibition, and/or a tour of the exhibition space itself.
  • Your funds will go towards gallery rental costs, reception costs, marketing costs, and framing costs.

The Impact

Mental health is a stigma, especially in the United States, but is still a huge problem that seems to be pushed under the table.  Via the National Alliance on Mental Illness, 20% of youth ages 13-18 live with a mental health condition.  Suicide is the third leading cause of death in youth ages 10-24  (10th leading cause of death nationwide) and 90% of those who died by suicide had an underlying mental illness.  50% of all lifetime cases of mental illness begin by age 14.  Depression is the leading cause of disability worldwide.  Our adolescence is some of the hardest times in our lives and for some people, like myself, it was the worst.  I want my exhibition to be a place for others to share their own stories and for youth who come to see that there is a light at the end of the tunnel, it does get better, and that this isn't the end of your life it is only the beginning.  I do not wish what I went through on my worst enemy but I want to take my experiences and turn them into something meaningful and helpful for others.  Forgiving Home will do just that.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute that's okay, here's how you can help:

  • You can come to my exhibition!  The exhibition will be held in Savannah, GA on May 17-19 at Sulfur Studios (2301 Bull St.) with a reception on the 18th.  Refreshments will be provided at the reception.  Come join the fun on my facebook event page: Click Here!
  • You can share my campaign with your friends, family, dog, imaginary friend, what have you!  Just click share on my campaign page!

I appreciate any and all help to make this dream a reality.  I can not wait for you to see Forgiving Home.

Courtney Ray

Photographer

http://courtneyrayphoto.com

To all my fans and analoque photography lovers, I have an offer for you. For anyone that will help me raise the fund for buying 8x10ín camera to experiment, create and teach my students, I will send a 'Thank You' poster so you can have a lovely reminder for being part of something really important and beautiful in the planet Earth. All you have to do is to make a donation of any amount you wish and write me a personal message OR choose from PERKS option so I could send you unique silver gelatine photograph made with this 8x10ín camera in the future. I can‘t promise how it will look like neither the subject or idea yet, but you can expect something from my upcoming project on astrophotography. Check my portfolio link for impression.

Give and get it back.  Support artist, enjoy the art.

story:
What is A Wonderland of Sins?

"Wonderland is a heterotopia, in which we explore things we don't have space to go into in our daily lives. Concepts of fun and temptation can be difficult, even seeming 'other'  and detached from the lives we try to live."

Hello! My name is Charlie Granby and I am a freelance photographer and filmmaker from Liverpool, U.K. I need your help... 

A Wonderland of Sins is a passion project of mine that has been in the works over recent months in order to bring together a diverse group of individuals to create art that I hope will contribute to the ever growing movement towards acceptance and understanding within the human race. 

It is a crossover of Alice in Wonderland and the 7 Deadly Sins. My reasoning for combining these two themes is because ultimately, I feel they complement each other well. The wacky, nonsensical nature of Wonderland combined with the shocking and somewhat disturbing nature of the 7 Deadly Sins, leads to a match that just makes sense to me. It's weird, it's quirky, and it's going to be hugely interesting to see how people respond.

But why is this important Charlie? Well, let me tell you!

In a world where people are encouraged to be lighter- both in skin tone and in weight, retouched images with stretch marks, spots and fat ironed out, mental health crisis and a skyrocket in eating disorders, body dysmorphia, racial hate crime; this project is breaking the taboo of everything. Society has used the Seven Deadly Sins against minorities to push them down, and this shoot aims to break that narrative. It's a big middle finger to all of it. What we should and shouldn't be, what we should and shouldn't do. None of the work will be photoshopped, you will see the raw beauty that these people possess.  It's about time we started emphasising inclusivity and diversity on multiple fronts. Skin colour, body shape and size, this project is encouraging everything and anything. We don't see that concept reflected as much in the media and in the arts- now is the time for change. 

If we can get this project into the studio and then out into the world, it would be such a huge achievement and it would make a difference. I want people to see this work and for it to be a very normal thing to have people of all races, sizes and genders/non binary in a group together. Let's break it down and make inclusivity part of every day life.

Government funding for the arts increasingly difficult to get. Unless you live in London, it's virtually impossible to get the funding you need, especially for women. The reality is, crowdfunding is our only viable option right now.

 

What We Need & What You Get

SO... we need to raise quite a lot of money, (just shy of £3000 eek!) This is to cover:

- Payment of models

- Payment of crew

- Food for the day

- Costume/Set design

- Equipment and production costs of the finished works

- Exhibition costs- venue hire, staffing, equipment

My team and I have come up with some exciting perks for those who claim one on donation. I personally am super excited by these, and I hope you will be too!

If we don't raise the full amount, then the money will be split as best possible so that we can try to get as much as we can out of it. Basically, I'm going to stop at nothing to make this project work!

The Impact

What your contribution means is that I, with the help of my amazing team, can bring to life an important and needed campaign to help shape the views in society towards race and body positivity. 

Additionally, I am planning a terribly exciting exhibition that will feature the work along with a panel discussion, live music and spoken word poetry. It's going to be an opportunity for important conversation around the whole theme of the shoot, so that new ideas can emerge and a foot can be put forward to mark the way of change. 

I am really excited by this project. I believe in this project, and I am so lucky to have the support from an incredible group of models and crew who have come aboard to make this work. My previous crowdfunds for projects such as my Curzon Soho/Crossrail film and Constellations, a stop-motion animation film which is in production, have both been a success- I want to make it a hatrick and bring this project to life!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If right now you aren't in a position to donate money, that is completely A-okay. What I ask however is that you help me spread the word- share this campaign, talk about it to your friends- let's get A Wonderland of Sins on people's map!

Any and all support is so appreciated and I am just so grateful to every person who tries to help. Honestly it means the world.

With all that being said, thank you so much for taking the time to be here on this page!

Be bold, be the change.

With all that being said, thank you so much for taking the time to be here on this page!Be bold, be the change.

story:
Since returning to photography in 2012, it has been a true rollercoaster of well, all of it. I have made a lot of wonderful new friends from all over and all walks of life, my work has found itself in the homes of people around the world, and of course other amazing opportunities and friendships that have come along with it. 

The road that has paved it all is by far not easy. Needless to say however, I am the worst sales person that I know of, which maybe, this is probably may be the best or worst idea I have come up with. 

The big secret is, my wonderful brother has been the biggest backer to what I have been doing. In 2012, he had noticed that I was getting [back] into photography and he saw the passion I had for it and how good I was getting. He had gifted (and mostly loaned) me some of his equipment (as he is a hobbyist) and I have been using it (putting it lightly) ever since. The time has come that I return his equipment to him, which includes one camera body and most of the lenses. 

Most of the world knows that photography (mostly of the entertainment field) does not pay well, if at all, and that most of my income has come from smaller jobs but most of all, from sales of my photography* (which of what is legally allowed). So, I am doing this little thing, which is in time for my birthday (9/19) to where I could persuade your heart to help me continue this path all of you have helped me get to.

He had gifted (and mostly loaned) me some of his equipment (as he is a hobbyist) and I have been using it (putting it lightly) ever since. The time has come that I return his equipment to him, which includes one camera body and most of the lenses. 
Most of the world knows that photography (mostly of the entertainment field) does not pay well, if at all, and that most of my income has come from smaller jobs but most of all, from sales of my photography* (which of what is legally allowed). So, I am doing this little thing, which is in time for my birthday (9/19) to where I could persuade your heart to help me continue this path all of you have helped me get to.

story:
The Void Series

The Void Series is comprised of two photography books full of dark inspiration. Check out what's inside and click on the individual perks to learn more about them!



Where do we go from here? Where we see darkness, there is a truth to be found in order to bring us somewhere beautiful.

Book I:


Into the Void: Into the Void: This is a book of mysterious and dark-yet-ethereal landscapes. It Includes a few tasteful artistic nudes.

"Introducing the nude to the landscape adds a sense of human vulnerability that isn't always there without the human figure. Being stripped of our self-built identity, our comfort, stripped from being placed in any particular time. Timeless. Connected to the Earth. "


 

 

Book II:

 

The Call of the Void:  This book is more on the macabre side of things, although both books reflect the concept of inner-darkness.

This is a book of portraits that conceals the identity of the individuals photographed. The purpose is to take something ordinary and shift it into something that tells a new story on a different level.




I am guaranteeing that all final orders arrive to you by September of 2020, if not sooner! I am willing to take down payments from those who can't afford a book right now to reserve one for later. $40 now and the rest when you can!  Please see the Reservations Tier!


Who am I?


The artist behind the shadows!

  • I am a visual artist among other things. My work lies somewhere between fine art and dark art. Considering most of my concepts, I prefer the term Dark Art. While most of my background is based in traditional art techniques, I have shifted to the digital age for my most recent imagery. By using a combination of body painting, digital photography, and digital art I am creating surreal, dream-like worlds.
  • I combine elements of life and death to create cohesive yet contrasting imagery. These images draw the viewer to question the story behind them and their dark but pleasant nature. Read more about my thoughts in the books!
  • My landscape photos have been compared to the style of photography known as near Infrared, initially produced by kodak aerochrome film.
  • These books include images from over the past four years. I am very dedicated to this project!
  • I am raising funds to make my first ever Dark Fine Art Photography book series.  
    I will be making two versions, a book of dark landscapes and one of the dark portraits. This will include a collection of images from 2016-2019. 
  • I am ready to share these with you! 

Vast, serene, dark, abandoned, empty, forgotten, solitude, peace, meditation, wanderer, curiosities, beauty, decay

What I Need & What You Get

Money for producing books! Books and Prints! Signed Prints, galore!

  • The purpose of reaching this goal is to make the books more affordable. If I do reach the goal, everyone who ordered a book gets a free gift! (it's a secret)
  • If I don't reach the goal, you still get what you ordered! 
  • Important! You have until June 10th to claim your items from this campaign! 60 days from the day I launch...
  • Why a $10,000 goal? Wholesale bulk orders just work that way. In order to make these as inexpensive for myself as well as for you, I have to order over 100+ books with no guarantee of selling more after this campaign.  Plus I also have to buy the materials to make all of my other items, pay for shipping to myself, feed myself and somehow still not go broke in the process! <3 
  • I would like to also add that for 2 of my items, I am offering 50% of all contributions for those go to the World Health Organization!!

Risks and Challenges

 

After months of research, sampling products, calling CEOs, making a spreadsheet of about 30 printing companies, their quality, pricing, and specs, I have narrowed my choice down to 3 printers.

I was initially going to have to hit my goal before I could do a bulk order of 100+ books to keep the cost down. I can still do that but I do not foresee this happening in the near future due to the questionable economy after the Covid19 Pandemic. 

Basically, If I reach my goal here, you get a free gift! If I do not reach my goal, you still get what you ordered or you can get a refund before the end of the campaign (June10th).

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you would share this with all of your friends, it would mean a lot to me! 
  • If you can't contribute right now, feel free to reach out to me with questions or follow me for future inspiration.

    Thank You!

story:
Hi! I’m Chris. Originally from Georgia, I spent most of my post-high school years living in parts of the US before settling in Canada for five years to study culture, visual communication, and artistic photography. I then decided to take an opportunity to move to Japan—something I've wanted to do for years—to explore this rich culture.

Since moving to Japan just this year, I’ve found myself living in and visiting more remote, lesser-known areas, and I felt the urge to start photographing these places and experiences. My career then slowly began with very minimal investment, and I now specialize in nature, lifestyle, and event photography. My education in artistic photography and visual communication led me to understand elements of photography and how they communicate different emotions and messages. I use what I've learned to capture the unique qualities of places, people, and events, preferring a style that speaks to deeper emotions rather than fleeting trends in digital photography.

 

 

While so far my photography career has involved only commercial work, I've also spent the year capturing and selecting several artistic series based on more unknown parts of Japan—away from over-saturated cities and popular tourist spots and deeper into hidden communities and forgotten places. I have a plan for 2019 to not only raise the quality of my commercial work, but also begin producing these series and offering high-quality prints online, at markets, and in galleries. 

 

 (selections from Makigama)

 

I’m asking for help to breathe new life into my photography career for the new year. A new camera body and an inexpensive lens, some necessary accessories, a year's worth of hosting an online print store—just enough to get some momentum. This time in my life has granted me wonderful opportunities to capture and share a unique part of the world through photography, and I expect next year to offer more of the same. I want to capture these places and experiences in best way possible and share it with the world.

(selections from Venus)

 

I’m offering high-quality prints to those who contribute. Once the funding is over, I’ll send a link to you with a wide selection of my photos. Choose your favorite photo, and I’ll send it your way! You also have the opportunity to receive one of five limited-edition, framed museum-quality prints that will not be available to anyone else outside of future gallery shows. Lastly, I plan to offer special discounts to my contributors once my online store is up and running—if you contribute, you'll receive the occasional e-mail from me with exclusive deals to my prints and other items.

 

(selections from untitled series)

 

I have more information in the FAQ—check it out if you’re curious! If you have any questions, or just want to say "hi," please send me a message. Thank you for stopping by :)

story:
The Man Behind the Lens

My name is Joshua and my love for photography stems from a dark room course I took in back in grade school. Over the past few years my hobby has morphed into an obsession ... here's why and how I plan on feeding that obsession in 2016.

Nearly five years ago I was diagnosed with a two rare diseases (Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension and Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia) and given roughly six months to live. I'm still alive, intent on enjoying life and seeing (and sharing) the unrelenting beauty of the world all around us.

On January 1st  of this year I started my first structured photographic journey called Project 365. If you're not familiar with the fad, it's basically a resolution to take and share one photo every day for one year. While we're not even half of the way through the year, I am incredibly excited to do this again next year ... but with a twist.

Project 365; A Year Behind the Macro Lens will be my introduction to the world of photomacrography. For 365 days I will take and share photos with a reproduction ratio of at least 1:1 - my goal in doing this will be to share with the world the unimaginable beauty of the microscopic, mundane and seemingly disgusting. After the project is completed, I will produce a hardcover, full color photo book to share with my supporters and the general public. 

The Funding

Tier One (If campaign is funded at $1,000.00)

  • Canon MP-E 65mm f/2.8 1-5X Macro Lens
    My current camera is a Sony point-and-shoot. I will be purchasing a nice DSLR camera with my own money before the project begins. I will, however, need a high-quality macro lens for this project.

Tier Two (If campaign is funded at $2,500.00)

  • Everything in Tier One plus:
  • Canon Macro Twin Lite MT-24EX

  • Novoflex CASTEL-CROSS-Q Macro focusing rails

Tier Three (If campaign is funded at $5,000.00)

  • Everything in Tiers One and Two plus:
  • Printing and distribution of the first order of Project 365: A Year Behind the Macro Lens photo book (500 copies)

What You Get

In addition to helping me with this project, your contribution will qualify you for a variety of amazing perks (see 'Perk' section for details)

Risks & Challenges

As with all things in life, unforeseeable obstacles may get in the way of the project's timely completion, however, I am fully committed to seeing this thing through. If any delays are necessary, you will be informed immediately.

Other Ways You Can Help

I completely understand that not everyone has the means to financially support this campaign. If you want to help, but can't make a financial contribution, please consider spreading the word!

  • Tell your friends and family about Project 365; A Year Behind the Macro Lens - and tell them why they should support it.
  • Share this page on Facebook, Google+, Twitter, Pinterest and anywhere else you can think of. (Indiegogo has handy-dandy 'share tools' to make this easy!)
  • Save a few bucks each month so you can get a copy of the book after the project is over.

story: My name is Sean Michael Beeman. I have been passionately using photography to support my love of music from bands local and from around the globe for 16 years. I have never asked for a penny. My love for music has never let money come in the way of my love of photography. I want to take my art to the next level and to make a viable business to support my art and love of music. What my goal is in the short term is to be able to sell prints and have nice custom frames built for them. I want to do this at a cost that keeps me in business and also is affordable to anyone interested. My initial goal is to build a stock of prints to sell at art shows, galleries, and on my website. Also using my website to promote music that we can all enjoy. I also want to build a financial basis for me to do photography for hire and eventually have my own studio and be a freelance photographer for hire. It's my time in my life to branch out my art and business to truly be the photographer I am truly meant to be. All proceeds will be documented on my website for all to see. I want to show my financial transparency and show everyone the power of their money in helping me reach my goal. Anyone that supports me I will happily come use my gift of photography for you. Please know this is my calling.  I have was born with a rare bone condition. It has caused me much physical and emotional pain, but I never let it stop me from my love for my art. I would like also to be a inspiration to anyone suffering from my condition or a debilitating condition. To show the world that pain can not stop one's personal self growth and determination. Please give what you can.

story:
Summary

  For more than 45 years I have been creating photographic art--singing a song with images and words.  I primarily shoot film and have a particular fondness for black and white film.  I’ve been called a motion and emotion photographer, specializing in performing arts, working with numerous professional theater and dance companies.  What I share is a passionate observation of my life, my times as a metaphor of humanity in these troubled times. What I have to show is a way of seeing, a way of life.  Since the 70's I have created images of people, musicians, dancers, poets, laborers, revolutionaries, artists.

The common man as an artist, life as creatively experienced not just existing.  I’ve photographed rock festivals, the Vietnam War, encounters with Abby Hoffman, and Gloria Steinem, just to name a few. I consider my images to be taken by a compassionate observer of the human condition.  

I seek to share my vision of humanity, through a journal of images and words, impressions on a life of photographic art. Poems, essays, tales real and surreal.  I wish to share a life in moments--from the wisdom of age returning to the freedom of  a child.

Contributors will help me with day to day and publishing expenses for this book.  I see this work as a lifelong self-portrait—told through poems, essays, and of course photographs.                                 Peter J. Crowley


What We Need & What You Get

This campaign will be an ongoing process.  The initial funding will be used to catalog my career's work, over 200,000 negatives and 400 pages of written copy.  To catalog these requires a lot of help, and I  would love to start paying my intern.  As great gratitude for you contribution,  you will receive a poster of my original photos from gallery shows (poster created by SL Johnson Images).  I am also offering prints of my words and images married together, a poem and photograph capturing the same emotion, telling a story.

The entire goal is to produce a 150 page book, a monograph comprised of words and images that spans my 45 year career.  If the goal isn't initially reached, the book may be published in installments.  No matter what, it will happen!


The Impact

 Previously, I published a book titled, "All the Usual Subjects" It was a limited-edition monograph reviewed and acclaimed throughout the world.  I've spent 45 years creating photographic art through a compassionate view of humanity.  This book will be a cohesive summary of the creative chapters in my life.  Through this book, I wish to show people my work--how I  fully immersed into a subject and created art in the viewfinder.


Risks & Challenges

My greatest fear is that the world is content with digital, cell phone images.  That the art world has permanently converted to 72 dpi and has no need for print.  I have followed the same photographic philosophy for 45 years--creating my art in the viewfinder, not in post production.  I live immersed, totally in the moment of the subject.  The images I created with this philosophy are what I wish to share with the world.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help financially, visit my website www.peterjcrowley.com.  Feel free to peruse my photos and comment on my blog posts.  That would be a huge help.   Thank you so much!

story:
The Backstory

Hi! I'm Angelica R. Jackson, a writer and artist in the foothills of the Sierra Nevadas.

I'm lucky to live close to a relatively-unknown landmark building, the former Preston School of Industry in Ione, California. Also known as Preston Castle, it was built in 1894 as a boys' reformatory and operated until about 1960, before being abandoned to the elements.

The only people to go inside for the next forty years or so were vandals, caretakers, and local kids. In the meantime, owls, foxes, bats, and other wild residents moved into the decaying structure. And, according to local stories (and even my own experiences), ghosts of the boys continue to haunt the hallways and rooms...

My first chance to go inside Preston Castle came in 2007, and the peeling paint, the smell of musty wood and brick, and the details of craftsmanship which remained, immediately captured my imagination.  I continued to take advantage of opportunities for private and public entry to the Castle over the next ten years, attempting to capture the play of shadows and light in the disused rooms.

Meanwhile, the Preston Castle Foundation was taking steps to preserve and protect the structure for later generations. In the course of restorations,  some of the original, arrested decay which attracted me to the building had been glossed over with fresh coats of paint. Traces left by the wards, and vandals, were disappearing between my visits, with photos being the only lasting proof.

The Goal

I want to bring my favorite images of this forgotten gem to a wider audience and I have assembled them into a photobook. The idea came to me after I printed a catalog of the images I was selling alongside my novel at a vendor booth in the Castle’s basement. I sold a decent amount of novels and photographs that day, but I got several requests to buy the catalog! Foundation members even suggested that I sell it in the gift shop.

Unfortunately, the version I’d brought to that event was too expensive to produce for sale. I’ve spent the time since then finding a printer (after some false starts, I ended up going with a POD model) and formatting the book. Its sixty pages contain ninety-nine images in a mixture of color and black & white.

The funding goal of $1500  is to cover expenses in producing/designing the book (I hired a cover designer and bought ISBNs), and printing an initial run of fifty copies. Perks and shipping supplies are included, as well as the fees which IndieGoGo and the credit card processors charge.

Some of the perks can ship in April, before the book order is placed, and those are marked accordingly. There aren’t any risks I can think of since I’m not launching this campaign until I have a finished version of the book that I like.

Now, onto the details about the perks!

The Postcard

This vintage-style image was actually shot in 2006, before they replaced the roof. And it does not appear in the book, so this is an exclusive perk for my IndieGoGo supporters! If the postcard perk is selected, it will be mailed to you (or the recipient of your choice). If selected as part of a bundle, it will be included (blank) in the package with the other perks.

 

The Novel

In 2014, Preston Castle inspired the setting of my young adult, urban fantasy novel. This darkly funny story is set in the fictional town of Crow’s Rest, with its own eerie Castle. This 2015 edition is now out-of-print (since I got my rights back), so get them before they disappear entirely! The eventual profits from Capturing The Castle will also help me release the sequel to Crow's Rest, called No Man's Land, through my Crow & Pitcher Press.

 

The Prints

When you select the perk for a print of a photo from the book, you will get a randomly-selected 8x10 or 8x12 print (size varies by photo), plus the postcard. You may specify color or black-and-white, and each ready-to-frame image comes labeled with a "c. _____" date to let you know when it was taken. Don't forget you can get more than one, if you'd like a collection of them on your wall!

 

The Photobook

Finally, we come to the book! If you select this perk, you'll get a signed copy of the perfect-bound, paperback printing of Capturing The Castle: Images of Preston Castle (2006-2016), which measures 7x10". This photobook includes 60 pages with 99 photos of the former Preston School of Industry; the Preston Castle Foundation has been restoring the structure, so some of these photos contain scenes lost to the repairs. The version in the video is a prototype (finished version will be slightly smaller at 7x10" vs. 8x11", and image selection/layout will vary)

In The Photobook Bundle perk, you will get the postcard, the Capturing The Castle photobook, a copy of the Crow's Rest YA UF novel, plus a print of the castle. << Best deal!

 

The Canvas Print

If you select this perk, you will get to choose a photo from my online gallery of Preston Castle photos, to be printed on a 12x16 canvas. The canvas is stretched and ready to hang, and I will sign it.

 

The Photoshoot

Angelica has booked a private photo shoot at Preston Castle on June 18, 2017, and you can join her! There will be at least one model on site, and of course there is the fantastic architecture (and possible ghostly manifestations) to photograph. I'm limiting this shoot to ten people total, so there are slots for seven people to join us. The Castle does offer Photographer's Days, but it can be a bit of a madhouse, so I want to share this chance to have the place to ourselves.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to contribute to this campaign, please take a moment to use the IndieGoGo share tools and help spread the word!

You can also find out more about Preston Castle and the Preston Castle Foundation on their website. Thank you so much for reading, and helping me reach my goal!
story_txt:
The Backstory
Hi! I'm Angelica R. Jackson, a writer and artist in the foothills of the Sierra Nevadas.
I'm lucky to live close to a relatively-unknown landmark building, the former Preston School of Industry in Ione, California. Also known as Preston Castle, it was built in 1894 as a boys' reformatory and operated until about 1960, before being abandoned to the elements.
The only people to go inside for the next forty years or so were vandals, caretakers, and local kids. In the meantime, owls, foxes, bats, and other wild residents moved into the decaying structure. And, according to local stories (and even my own experiences), ghosts of the boys continue to haunt the hallways and rooms...
My first chance to go inside Preston Castle came in 2007, and the peeling paint, the smell of musty wood and brick, and the details of craftsmanship which remained, immediately captured my imagination.  I continued to take advantage of opportunities for private and public entry to the Castle over the next ten years, attempting to capture the play of shadows and light in the disused rooms.
Meanwhile, the Preston Castle Foundation was taking steps to preserve and protect the structure for later generations. In the course of restorations,  some of the original, arrested decay which attracted me to the building had been glossed over with fresh coats of paint. Traces left by the wards, and vandals, were disappearing between my visits, with photos being the only lasting proof.
The Goal
I want to bring my favorite images of this forgotten gem to a wider audience and I have assembled them into a photobook. The idea came to me after I printed a catalog of the images I was selling alongside my novel at a vendor booth in the Castle’s basement. I sold a decent amount of novels and photographs that day, but I got several requests to buy the catalog! Foundation members even suggested that I sell it in the gift shop.
Unfortunately, the version I’d brought to that event was too expensive to produce for sale. I’ve spent the time since then finding a printer (after some false starts, I ended up going with a POD model) and formatting the book. Its sixty pages contain ninety-nine images in a mixture of color and black & white.
The funding goal of $1500  is to cover expenses in producing/designing the book (I hired a cover designer and bought ISBNs), and printing an initial run of fifty copies. Perks and shipping supplies are included, as well as the fees which IndieGoGo and the credit card processors charge.
Some of the perks can ship in April, before the book order is placed, and those are marked accordingly. There aren’t any risks I can think of since I’m not launching this campaign until I have a finished version of the book that I like.
Now, onto the details about the perks!
The Postcard

This vintage-style image was actually shot in 2006, before they replaced the roof. And it does not appear in the book, so this is an exclusive perk for my IndieGoGo supporters! If the postcard perk is selected, it will be mailed to you (or the recipient of your choice). If selected as part of a bundle, it will be included (blank) in the package with the other perks.
 
The Novel

In 2014, Preston Castle inspired the setting of my young adult, urban fantasy novel. This darkly funny story is set in the fictional town of Crow’s Rest, with its own eerie Castle. This 2015 edition is now out-of-print (since I got my rights back), so get them before they disappear entirely! The eventual profits from Capturing The Castle will also help me release the sequel to Crow's Rest, called No Man's Land, through my Crow & Pitcher Press.
 
The Prints

When you select the perk for a print of a photo from the book, you will get a randomly-selected 8x10 or 8x12 print (size varies by photo), plus the postcard. You may specify color or black-and-white, and each ready-to-frame image comes labeled with a "c. _____" date to let you know when it was taken. Don't forget you can get more than one, if you'd like a collection of them on your wall!
 
The Photobook

Finally, we come to the book! If you select this perk, you'll get a signed copy of the perfect-bound, paperback printing of Capturing The Castle: Images of Preston Castle (2006-2016), which measures 7x10". This photobook includes 60 pages with 99 photos of the former Preston School of Industry; the Preston Castle Foundation has been restoring the structure, so some of these photos contain scenes lost to the repairs. The version in the video is a prototype (finished version will be slightly smaller at 7x10" vs. 8x11", and image selection/layout will vary)
In The Photobook Bundle perk, you will get the postcard, the Capturing The Castle photobook, a copy of the  Crow's Rest YA UF novel, plus a print of the castle. << Best deal!
 
The Canvas Print

If you select this perk, you will get to choose a photo from my online gallery of Preston Castle photos, to be printed on a 12x16 canvas. The canvas is stretched and ready to hang, and I will sign it.
 
The Photoshoot

Angelica has booked a private photo shoot at Preston Castle on June 18, 2017, and you can join her! There will be at least one model on site, and of course there is the fantastic architecture (and possible ghostly manifestations) to photograph. I'm limiting this shoot to ten people total, so there are slots for seven people to join us. The Castle does offer Photographer's Days, but it can be a bit of a madhouse, so I want to share this chance to have the place to ourselves.
 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you're not able to contribute to this campaign, please take a moment to use the IndieGoGo share tools and help spread the word!
You can also find out more about Preston Castle and the Preston Castle Foundation on their website. Thank you so much for reading, and helping me reach my goal!

story:
My Story:

I'm a small business photographer. I love what I do and I have had a DSLR camera of some kind for over 10 years. I started Veronica Nelson Photography in January of 2018. In one year, I have grown significantly. I continue to watch seminars and videos, read blogs, and practice every day. It is my goal to be able to support my family 100% with my photography in 5 years. 

Taking the next step:

I'm seeking to raise $3000.00 towards startup costs for my business. I will use this money:

-To purchase new gear, specifically a new camera. This is by far the biggest expense but will provide me with more advantages when it comes to lower lighting situations and it will also provide me with higher quality photos straight out of camera which is very important to me and for my customers. 

-For in home studio equipment. I will purchase a couple of soft boxes to give me more light inside my home studio space, a better lens for those close up photos, a backdrop setup (for milestone photos, school photos, etc.) and newborn photo necessities. Having a home studio will greatly expand the services I can offer and I will be able to provide year round photos and a warm location for customers without weather playing a significant factor. Living in Alaska, we experience very long and cold winters so weather is usually a pretty important factor. 

-On advertising. I will have about $300-$500 left for advertising purposes. I would like to create an actual website and use an SEO to help drive traffic to the site, I would like to create magnets to deliver to businesses (pre-natal doctor offices and pediatric offices) and I would like to collaborate with other small businesses that can help get my name out. 

How you can help:

You can help me reach my goal and support my small business by making a pledge. 

Pledges will get you free sessions:

$50 pledge gets you two mini 30-45min sessions ($100+ value with prices to increase) to use in 2019.

$250 pledge gets you two full 1.5hr sessions and three mini 30-45min sessions ($300+ value with prices to increase) to use in 2019. 

$500 pledge gets you four full 1.5hr sessions and six mini 30-45min sessions (currently a $600+ value with prices to increase) to use in the 2019 & 2020 year. This is by far the best value and great for anyone who is currently expecting, just had a baby or are planning to get married soon.  

Or if you are an out-of-state family member or someone who has wanted to support my business but does not want any photo sessions you can make a donation. Every little bit helps!

In summary:

I love what I do and 2019 is a year of growth. This money will help me create better images, offer more services, and attract more clients so that I can provide for my family. The campaign will run for 30 days. If I do not raise the entire amount, I will use what is raised towards one of these start up costs. As always, I appreciate everyone's help and support! You all mean the world to me and my family!

story:
Join us to celebrate a week long exhibition by 69 local, national and international students from the BA (Hons) Photography course at Falmouth University. 

 

Every year the 2nd Year Photography students hold an end of year exhibition, showcasing the culmination of their year-long endeavours. This year’s students not only seek to redefine the use, function and role of photography in the 21st century, but to also define and determine their own futures within today’s Brexit discourse. 

 

Working in photography, video, installation and performance, Nova is a group exhibition highlighting a diverse range of approaches to each students practice, illustrating each individuals perspective of the world around us. The word Nova has its origins in the late 19th century: from Latin, feminine of novus ‘new’ (because such stars were thought to be newly formed). We therefore wish to shine a beacon of light on the achievements within our photographic practices thus far, and imagine what kind of creatives we might become in the future.

story:
"The last thing a homeless person needs is a camera."

That quote came directly from a comment on an article on a local media site that featured the project. I would agree that in terms of physical needs, a camera does not go very far in providing food, shelter or clothes. However, a camera is exactly what many of our photographers needed to experience joy, hope and fulfillment.

How it all began

We started the Through Our Eyes Project in 2016 by giving out 86 cameras to the homeless in Spartanburg, South Carolina. We asked them to photograph their lives - where they went, who they spent time with, what they valued. The results were incredible. The devastation we saw on the street was shocking. The hope and optimism that many saw despite their situation was encouraging. Their participation was humbling.

Each person received a care bag, a t-shirt that gave them the title of 'photographer' for the week, extra clothes and food. A prayer team was there to help them heal spiritually and provide some hope. A team of judges narrowed down over 800 photos to a top 20 (a hard thing to do!) that hung in an art gallery for a month. The community was invited to come and vote for their favorite photos by placing spare change in a lockbox next to the images that stood out to them. All the money raised went to support local organizations that care for the homeless. The three photographs that received the most money earned prizes for those photographers to help meet their needs.

The response from the community was so great that we took the project to Greenville, South Carolina, a neighboring city with an even bigger homeless population.

Why do an Indiegogo campaign?

We believe in the impact this project has had in our communities and we believe that it can impact many others. Our goal is to print a beautiful 128-page coffee table photography book. We want to provide an opportunity for a permanent, printed piece of the project to be made available. Our gallery exhibits last 30 days, but the books can live on and continue to inspire. Of course, we want people to buy the books, but we also want some to be in schools and libraries, and in the hands of the photographers who took the photos.

What we're looking for

We want to raise $10,000.

The funds raised from this campaign will help offset the costs relating to:

  • layout & design
  • printing the first run of books
  • purchasing ISBN numbers, barcodes and copyrights
  • marketing
  • shipping
  • swag & incentives

Speaking of incentives...

We've got some great perks for you including a limited edition, individually numbered hardcover book, first run t-shirt not offered anywhere else, postcard sets, prints and even an opportunity to put your name in our book as a contributor.

"I feel like I have a purpose, if only for a week."

That's what a photographer told us last year. He was empowered. The proceeds we make from the book sales will help us take the project to new cities and countries and reach more groups of people who are marginalized, vulnerable and need a voice. We want to continue to provide a message of hope and the joy that comes with creating art. You can help make this happen.

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest risk is inactivity. It's the same risk that happens in our communities every day. People drive by someone on the street. There's no eye contact. There's no emotion. There's no desire to help. We want to overcome this by intentionally making people confront homelessness in a real way. I don't see a person on the street anymore. I see Chris or Tonya. I can tell that Scotty got a haircut. I notice when David doesn't come around as much. Even though these names are from Spartanburg, South Carolina, the problem is everywhere.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some reading this can't commit to buy a book. That's perfectly fine. Make a difference in your city. Help in these other ways:

  • Pray. Pray specifically for three things. 1) That homelessness can be eradicated in your city. 2) For the physical, spiritual and emotional needs of the people on the street. 3) For others to take action.
  • Share this page! You might not be able to invest in the campaign, but you know people who can. Share this and help make a difference, one camera at a time.

The cameras are disposable. The people are not.

story:
First off, I would love to be able to take better pictures of bugs. The ones I currently am taking are Winnipeg specific, and merely taken with my camera phone. I one day hope to make them spectacular, and possibly from more than just this location!

 

I wish to educate the world on bugs, one picture at a time. It's always been a fascination and hobby of mine, so why not share it with others? Once I get a stellar collection of photos (which I know I can do), I would love to publish them and possibly make it into a book. It would be a lifelong goal and dream. 

 

Any and all support helps! Thank you!
